reviews.review:
Lemongrass is in the beautiful Aria Resort and Casino Hotel.  The atmosphere is breathtakingly beautiful!!  

Pros:
1) Excellent service
2) Food was great (Ordered the pad thai with beef)
3) Huge menu variety (including dim sum)
4) Clean and new
5) Quiet atmosphere

Cons:
1) On the pricier end
2) Location of the restaurant was tucked in so it was kind of hard to find

This was our last dinner in Vegas and we had a craving for Thai. Chose Lemongrass at The Aria based on the menu, and we were not disappointed.

I had the Panang Curry with Duck and honestly, it was the best panang curry I've ever had in my life. Fantastic flavor, even without the duck itself. It was so delicious, I could have eaten probably three more orders of it. We also started off with the veggie spring rolls and they were quite the tasty appetizer.

The place was pretty busy about 7:30pm on a Friday night, so we ate at the bar. Service was excellent - great attitude, very attentive. Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our meal.

I will forever be going back to Lemongrass in Vegas, specifically for that panang curry!

After some great experiences with the other eateries inside the Aria hotel, we decided to stop by Lemongrass for lunch.  Being right outside the Sky Suites entrance, we must have walked past this restaurant dozens of times. However, we noticed that it was never really busy - a possible indication of quality?  We decided to try for ourselves.

We walked up to the host stand and asked for a table for two for lunch.  We were sat promptly.  This is where the promptness of service ended.  After what seemed like a longer than normal amount of time, a server came over and took our drink orders.  We ordered hot jasmine tea and water.  After another extended period of time, we received our drinks and we placed our order.  The appetizers, as well as entrees, were brought out at different times, but not as a regulated course approach, but more like bringing out as they are prepared.  This seems to reflect poor execution of timing on the kitchen's part.

For appetizers, we ordered Jellyfish, Potstickers, and Chicken Satay.  The jellyfish dish was delicious.  Crisp, fresh, with a hint of sesame, but not so much that it overpowered the dish.  The potstickers and chicken satay were unremarkable but good.

Our lunch order consisted of Phad Thai and Basil Fried Rice.  Both dishes were good, safe, prepared correctly with nothing remarkable, and not any different or better than any local strip mall Thai restaurant.  In all reality, I've had better at certain strip mall Thai restaurants.

I expected more from a restaurant within the walls of the Aria.  When compared to the likes of barMasa, it is a huge difference in the quality of service and food.
Its a bit pricey for thai food but you're in Vegas and in a hotel at the strip. Restaurant week special is a must try, price is better than anything on the menu.
Delicious yellow curry and drunken noodles. Pair it with a fresh young coconut water and the meal was pure heaven! Highly recommended!

Had the pad thai and chicken wings.  The first 2 pieces of steak in the pad thai i had to spit out cause it was chewy, very gross.  Low quality meat.  The chicken wings werent anything special.  I wouldnt go back

Lovely atmosphere.  Attentive and knowledgeable service.  That being said, the food was just ok.  The shrimp was pre-cooked and reheated, not freshly prepared.  The portions were generous, but underwhelming in taste.
Amazing! Once we walked in the smell of Thailand greeted us...We ordered pad thai, green curry and lobster, every dish was outstanding!!!

Love this place and will definitely return on our next trip to Las Vegas.  We ate here for lunch and they were still serving dim sum.  Although the dim sum isn't totally authentic, the items we had were still really good!
We enjoyed several of the items off of the regular menu as well.  I can't remember the names of the dishes but one was a mixed seafood salad that had a nice kick to it and the other was wonton noodle soup.  I wouldn't recommend the wonton noodle soup because it was bland but it was the only disappointment in the whole meal.

Overpriced and slow service.  Pho was bland and you have to ask for Sriracha otherwise you just have it as is.  Reservations needed even though there's plenty of open seats.  It was weird.  Servers were friendly and place was clean.
It was late and we were hungry.  I've had better Thai cuisine, although the prices were reasonable.

Was starving and came here for dinner right after going to the Big Bang concert at Mandalay Bay.  It was one of the restaurants that was open late at night and close by our hotel.  We ordered the beef red curry, chicken rad nah and tai chen chicken.  The food tasted good.  Service was good.  But it was a bit expensive, but again, it's Vegas so what do you expect.  Also, for a not so busy restaurant, it took awhile for the food to come out.  The waiter was nice and attentive and our waters were filled quickly.  The restaurant wasn't that busy at that time of night.  Its your basic thai food-nothing fancy or special, but overpriced.

Get the curry crab!  Ok i know its $65 dollars, and you can get it in Canada for much cheaper, but hey you are in Vegas so you might as well indulge.  The service is very good as i think it should when everything is so overpriced.  The quality of the food is fresh, but it won't wow you out of your pants.  
One thing i enjoyed is that they do have dim sum service in the mornings which was a big pleasnt suprise for me when i stayed at Aria.  Instead of waiting in line for the cafe/bakery/buffet, get some dim sum.  Avoid the pho/ noodles as they are a tad bit diluted.

The prices here are a bit expensive for what the food is. The beef and pork noodle soup was good. The broth tasted like the authentic my dad makes. 

The three stars is due to the fact that most of the meat was chunks of fat and my choy had dirt in it. I didn't realize until the last piece because I but down and felt the grit in my teeth. There was also dirt at the bottom of my bowl from not washing the vegetable thoroughly. For such an expensive bowl of noodles I would've expected cleanliness...

Most of the restaurants I've chosen in Vegas I've been happy with but Lemongrass not so much. Overall, the Aria is a slightly strange place. The rooms are amazing - so comfortable, amazing touch screen technology to control everything in the room, bathtub in the shower area, etc. That said, the hotel lobby is gloomy, the casino is very dark, the club is just okay, and the casino tables are not lucky!

Back to Lemongrass though. It's thai-fusion and not all I'd hoped for especially with how much I love thai food. I'd be happier with more "normal" thai food than this spot. We tried to get the seaweed salad to start but had to send it back because it was so strange and fishy. The other dishes were not memorable either and it wasn't inexpensive. We had wine which was pretty good but the food was just not worth it. If I were to stay at the Aria again, I'd choose other restaurants for sure. I'm actually a bit surprised that Lemongrass is still there.
Expensive and overly salty with their dishes. Can't see this place lasting into the future.

We ordered the Jelly Fish and Fried Squid Apps. Our entrees were  the Drunken Seafood Noodle dish and BBQ Duck soup! Everything was incredible! It took a while between Apps and Entrees but the staff was friendly and treated us very well. We will certainly be back!!

I'm very confused by the previous reviews as we had a FABULOUS dining experience!  We made reservations before seeing Zarkana so as soon as the show was over, we headed to dinner. We were greeted by Bank, our waiter and he was great! We ordered drinks to start and then decided on dinner. I went with the cashew chicken dish and an order of the pork fried rice. 
The food came out within 15 minutes. 
That fried rice was one of the best I have ever had! Great flavors!! The chicken was very tender and fresh!  I enjoyed every bite! ! Bank was very attentive during the entire dinner.  Definitely eat here as you won't be disappointed! !

Are you people on crack? This food was downright awful! First time in Vegas, and I was ready for some awesome food. We were staying at the Aria, and Thai is one of my favorite cuisines, so I thought we'd play it safe by eating at Lemongrass.

We started with calamari, one of my favorite foods, and it was chewy, bland, and all around blah. The other appetizer we got was the jellyfish, which is probably the only thing I would recommend--loved the sesame flavor. My entree, the Drunken Noodles, was horrendous. Flavor was bland even though I requested it "very spicy" and the seafood was even worse. It seemed like they just cooked it separately and threw it on top, and it wasn't even that fresh. Maybe the Southwest just isn't an Asian food mecca, but I didn't think Central Pennsylvania was either, and I have had much better Thai food back home. This food isn't just Americanized, it's gross, and especially at this price I'd definitely recommend getting your Thai fix elsewhere. To top it off, the service was a little too pushy for my taste...they kept trying to get us to order more! It was creepy!

On that note, I highly recommend the drinks here, and the atmosphere is nice. Next time I'll stick to the bar and jellyfish (well, I don't think there will be a next time actually. Sorry, Lemongrass).

You have to try this place in the Aria casino. Everything is good. I eat here 2 times a year - which is exactly how many times a year I am in Vegas. 

Wings are fantastic. 

Pad thai is killer. Get it a little hot. I got it at a 7. 

Pepper beef udon- amazing. 

Soooooo good. :)

Not impressed flavors pretty blah and you have to buy rice to go with your dish (i.e curry). Go to Weera Thai off strip on Sahara/Valley view your belly and your wallet will be so much happier...I promise!!

Lemongrass does a pretty decent job at selecting authentic Thai dishes. However, dishes that were tasted did not stand out from other Thai restaurants (e.g. pad thai, sweet and sour chicken). Though some of the dishes may not have that "wow factor," there are some that are pretty decadent. I'm talking about their red curry. It's amazingly flavorful immaculate Thai dish. Just make sure to not order it too spicy otherwise you won't get to indulge in its rich flavor. Try out the coconut ice cream. It is sublime.

Delicious! We were staying at Vdara and found this place walking around Aria and decided to make a reservation. We went with a large group and I think everyone liked their food. I ordered yellow curry and some wine, and both were tasty. For dessert we ordered the mango sticky rice, fried banana, and something with coconut (I can't remember what it was). All of those were awesome. The prices were also decent--I think my meal was ~$15 or so, but they had more expensive/fancy entrees if that's what you're into. The service was also super friendly and fast. We waited the perfect amount for our food--not too short (where you feel rushed and wonder if they even cooked your food) but not too long. Our waiter Chun was great. I'd definitely love to go here again, especially because I always get cravings for Thai food. It's good to know next time I get a craving in Vegas.

One cannot really expect authentic Thai food from a restaurant in a fancy schmany Vegas hotel. 

Knowing that, the food is good. My uncle reserved the private room for my family to celebrate my mom's birthday, and he preordered the food ahead of time so I don't know what everything was called. 

He also ordered way too much food, not knowing what the portions would be like, which are decent-sized. We had pad thai, some sort go orange chicken, tilapia, fried rice, etc, but the two that stood out to me were the crab cake/pancake (my little brother is annoyingly picky, but he loved this dish) and the seafood curry (nice spices, and it was different from everything else I've tasted). 

I also ordered one of their specialty drinks, the Berry Botanical, which was a green tea infused gin with whole blueberries. It was really refreshing, and they were not stingy with the alcohol, which I appreciate. 

The ambience is what you would expect of Vegas, trendy, clean and modern with dim, mood lighting. The service was great. My family didn't like the tiny individual plates they gave us, and our server was more than happy to replace them with bigger plates.

Average Asian fusion. Has an impressive dimsum selection - shrimp dumplings, bean curd, pan-fried turnip cake were good. Xiao long bao is only average - much better at Red 8 at Encore. Drunken noodle with seafood had plenty of basil and fresh seafood (calamari was excellent), but presentation needs work. Lunch is reasonably priced. Love the setting - very calm, tastefully done. Service was excellent.

Came to this place thinking I was going to have Thai food seeing as it is a Thai restaurant, but we found out that they actually have dim sum every day of the week, so we couldn't resist. I live in Southern California, so I we have plenty of restaurants that have authentic Chinese dim sum and this place actually held its own with them. The dim sum was exactly what I've had at other quality dim sum restaurants. One drawback: dim sum for 3 people ended up costing me over $80....Kind of a pricey lunch.

The ambiance is great! You would have thought you'll get the best service too but I guess it is not always the case. We had a late dinner so we didn't really have a difficult time getting a space for a party of 5. We ordered  Tom Yum for a starter.  The waiter managed to brought in the soup, 5 bowls & 5 spoons on our table in one shot. Almost perfect! except he didn't bring a ladle. He turned away but I  called his attention just in time before he disappear from my eye sight, I asked for a ladle, he replied and said " Sorry, there's no ladle in the kitchen.!" Seriously?? We were shocked by what he said, how does he expect us to scoop the soup with? this is just a common sense! Oh well, we decided not to ruin our night just because of that so we just started scooping it with our soup spoon. hmm... Nice Resto inside a 5 star hotel and yet couldn't afford a laddle.. After few minutes, the same waiter came back with a ladle but we were half way done scooping the soup! He probably realized how stupid his excuse was! The main entree came next..the food is mediocre but i will have to give 5 stars on the Thai Crab Omelette, i really enjoyed this one. We also had this Garlic and Lime Steamed cod. It's looks so good! but the taste was a total opposite. We actually  returned and cancelled this menu because the fish was either not fresh or not cooked well... I am mainly giving them 3 stars because of my overall experience..

Lunch Review ...

Friend had a craving for Thai food, so we decided to have lunch at Lemongrass.  When we sat down, I was surprised to learn that they were also serving dim sum (not sure if this is a regular part of their menu or limited to Sundays is often the case at Chinese restaurants) and admittedly a little wary ... as I've found that most restaurants that mix cuisines end up doing none of them well.

Thai Food - My friend ordered "Drunken Noodle with Seafood," which was not bad but not necessarily good (a little on the bland side and skimpy on the seafood) ... how about mediocre.

Dim Sum - To my surprise, the dim sum was pretty good.  I didn't order much (so my review is based on three dishes only), but what I ordered was enjoyable:  (1) Leek and Shrimp Dumplings - Less like a traditional dumpling (with a distinct flour wrapper you might associate with a potsticker), but still okay; (2) Turnip Cake - Very good, and I am a HUGE fan of turnip cakes; and (3) Ginger Scallion Tripe - Also very good, and I am also a HUGE fan of tripe.

Food was bad. Service was beyond bad... The only dish we cared for was the shrimp spring roll. Everything else was poorly put together. Main dish was cold. Waiter never came to us to check up on us. We didn't finish our plates and we did not pack to go. Stay away... We will be complaining.

Stopped in with a coworker on our way to a meeting. I explained we were in a rush and the were very happy to help. The service was fantastic, the food came out very quickly and it tasted great. 

Five star service, four star food.

I'd definitely go back, especially if I had more time to enjoy the experience.

I have been visiting Lemongrass for almost a decade, solid 4 stars on food, service is not consistent but usually pretty good. I have tried just about every single item on their menu, and as anywhere else I do have some favorites. 

I'll start with the best of the best, make sure to order their Maine  Lobster with ginger & scallions sauce, there is a salt & pepper option but not as yummy. 

Noodles, Their Cantonese chow mein is very good,  Pad Thai is good but too sweet for my taste.

Soups, my favorites are Tom Kha chicken or lobster, and their Sweet & Sour, both great, there is also a  vegetarian Tom Kha option, the Wonton noodle soup is also very good, but I like the other two best.

Dessert, sticky mango rice is excellent.

Considering it's location, and portions, menu prices are very good. 

There are several excellent restaurants at Aria, however, if you are in the mood for Asian food, Lemongrass is an excellent option.

mangia!

Love this place! The service is top notch and the Penang Duck Curry is stellar! We always come here when we come to Vegas and it never disappoints us. Great and calm ambience that is very romantic. Good for late night because it's empty!!

* Price: reasonable comparing to anything else in this resort;   $70 for two (papaya salad, drunken noodle, beef pho and 2 thai ice tea); 4 + star. 
* Ambiance: modern , beautiful decor! 4 + star. 
* Location: inside of the Aria resort, across from Blossom.  3 star.
* Meals: fresh,  tasty,  more like asian medley... not just thai food. There is Chinese and Vietnamese dishes on their menu as well.  Large portion! 4 star.
* Service: pleasant, fast and polite! 4+ star.

This is averaged to 4+ star for me. Since it opens until
2 Am, I added another 1/2 star!

We stayed at the Aria to see Jason Mraz concert... so we did not get any discount or perk on resort and food... 
We came here around 1 AM and they still sit people! The service was good (some reviewers complained about the service!) The waiters were very polite and pleasant. 
Anyway,  our drink and food came out at a good pace. The papaya salad is fresh and perfect. Drunken noodle is basically Thai Parseew which is a flat white noodle stirred fried with seafood in soy sauce.  The beef pho is pretty tasty. The meat is very tender. All portions are large! We were pretty full after the meal! It is quite tasty and comfort especially after a late night drinking!
We were glad to have a great meal at this late beside pizza!

We were skeptical at first because of some bad reviews on yelp... but we're surprised about this place. Could not believe they got 1 or 2 star (someone must have had a bad day! ) 
You can easily spend $50 for a sandwich and salad at Jean Phillips and minimal $100 per person at other joints in Aria! So, c'mmon people... This place is deserved some Kudo!

One Word Jellyfish, 8 bucks probably not going to like it but you have to say you did it. kinda like flavored dry silicone beads. Everything  was really good. satay was excellent. The Kua gui was very good, and super spicy sesame chicken, 7 on a 10 of heat. over all a very good meal, a nice fusion Thai here, the hot spice was awesomely hot, yum,
the service was the only iffy part, but everyone was really nice and we had everything we needed.

Their dishes doesn't taste like authentic Thai food, but I love their rib eye steak with tamarind sauce. I also usually get yellow or green curry chicken. The ambiance is nice & family style feel. Their service is really good, on time, and friendly. I've been coming here the last 4 years and their service is usually A plus and the wait for our food is pretty quick. My friends and I also like coming here for late night quality food since they close pretty late. Over all, I would give it a 3.5.

WE reserved a table for a party of six and we had a really nice dinner.  We tried some unusual items like Jelly fish (Not that impressive), but all of the staple Thai dishes were great.  For six people we ordered "family style" (six main dishes and 3 appetizers).  the portions were good and the food was excellent.

This just hit the spot.  I stopped in for a light meal and decided to enjoy it at the bar.  The bartender was great and made a cocktail suggestion that paired well with my food.
The Tom Kha Chicken soup was $8 and large enough that I could have stopped there.  The flavors were bright and balanced and it really hit the spot.  I also had their Spicy Papaya Salad and it truly was spicy.  It tasted so fabulous that I wanted to keep eating, but my tongue finally threw in the towel after the tears started coming.

Despite reading reviews I often go into a restaurant with an open mind because I'm conscience that everyone's taste is different. 

Unfortunately I was quite disappointed (after ordering the Red Duck Curry)! Almost want to say that this was the worst Thai I've had. I remember recently saying to a friend I don't think there's a things such as "bad" Thai and I've been proven wrong tonight. 

I often eat Thai food including northern and southern CA, New York, Canada, London, Paris and of course Thailand so I know a bit about Thai food. Ps I hardly ever write reviews but I felt compelled to write one, given that visiting Vegas where majority of restaurants are overpriced...I think it should be a guaranteed good and tasty meal! 
Of almost forgot the Thai ice tea actually was good.
Food is excellent along with the server. They made mistake with the viet tea and they fix it. Order the duck red curry mild and it taste really good. Highly recommended

Know what's funny? When I'm a few clicks from Chinatown/SGV at home I rarely feel like eating dim sum. Send me to the epicenter of hookers, blow and blowing hookers and I instantly crave it like clockwork (the dim sum, not the prostitutes/drugs); it always hits right around 10:44am on the 1st morning waking up in Vegas. Pft, like I'm gonna leave the Strip to go get sum dim sum...no. NO! YOU CAN'T MAKE ME GET IN THE CAR! No-oh...there's a place in ARIA?! Okie =)

Chinese-Thai fusion -- to my stomach that translates to: dim sum and satay. Asian soul food and tropical shee-at. I feel only the slightest bit bad because LG has been deserving of four stars my previous two visits but with the last one, well, let's just say third time was NOT the charm. Hehehekekekejajajaja. Amirite? Yah, I am totes rite.

Aside from ordering your typical assortment of spherical balls of crap enveloped in cocoons of some sort of rice-based skin (as an Asian I feel pretty ashamed I don't even know what I'm talking about) such as har gow, pork bao, shao mai, turnip cake, etc. you can of course get Thai dishes. No lie, we've probably ordered 90% of the same thing each visit while sometimes changing it up and subbing out a dim sum plate for something else. Can I mention how cute the phrase daan taat is? Egg custard cups...they even look adorable. If I could personify this dish I'd want to squeeze its cheeks, slap it in the face then swiftly punt it into a wall because it's just too gosh darn ky00t. Daan taat in animal form is a maltese =)

To regain focus on the foodles...the beef satay disappointed us this time around. In fact, most of the dim sum disappointed too. Did it taste skanky like a used diaper laced with pencil shavings? Nah, it tasted decent like always but the temp...argh. Such a seemingly simple aspect when serving food but tough to execute correctly on a consistent basis. All the dishes were either a couple of degrees above being lukewarm or getting dangerously close to flat out cold...clearly not the optimal temp to serve dim sum or meat on a stick in a pineapple under the sea. It's almost as though the carts were circling the depths of hell for a few mins too long...and by hell, I mean Lemongrass. And by mins, I mean a maybe a half-hour or so. The worst was the satay -- the surface temp completely turned me off since I felt like I was basically licking a cold cow popsicle...ahhhhh!

It doesn't help that without fail, at least two people order the young coconut. 12 mothafluffin' dollars per...that's a 6 or 8 place bet in crapaud =( I mean, they're alright but I don't see what the big deal is with these stupid nuts. In particular on this last trip the examples we were served weren't ripe so it was tough to scrape the meat off and it wasn't exactly sweet flavored. Kinda slimy too, akin to squid...blech.

Still, I won't let this deter me. Yes, you can bet your sweet fanny I'll be updating LG when I revisit in a few months. Plz to be turning the heat up a few degrees on your stoves and grils?

I came here for dinner with my bf on a recent trip to Vegas. We were staying at the Aria, so decided to grab a quick bite before watching KA. We ordered the prawn rolls as an appetizer; I ordered the Pad See Ew J (vegetarian). Overall, I think the food was okay in taste, but fairly pricey. I've definitely had more authentic Thai food for cheaper. I did order a glass of yummy Dragonstone Riesling :)

-L.

Best service in aria. They are casual dinning at the Aria. But still classy. Dimly light Asian themed decor. Comfortable seating for groups and accommodating for babies. Huge bonuses for vegas with baby and group of friends. 
If you are here on the weekends they have dimsum. And some of the best dimsum dishes I have had in the United States. Everything was fresh and tasty. Not overly salty and not overly oily. We got the ribs and chicken feet. We also got the stick rice wrapped in banana leave with chicken. Really very authentic. 
On the side I order abalone congee and a spicy beef noodle soup. The congee was perfectly cooked. There were lots of abalone in the congee. Usually other restaurants really skimp on that and give just a couple slices. The beef noodle soup was not as great. The beef tendon was really hard and the broth was kinda on the sour side. 
We basically had a wonderful dinning experience and for the rest of our four day trip we kept coming for lunch and late night snack. Open till 2 am!!

I go to Vegas a bit too much at times and Lemongrass is a great escape from the usual steak/fish dinners. It's conveniently located at Aria and they're open late!  

I usually go for the prawn rolls, satay combos, panang duck and mee goreng street noodles. Try the Thai spice drink, it's like a rum spiked Thai iced tea. But I don't get sticking the lime on the glass. Maybe a pineapple or shaved coconut would be more appropriate, just a suggestion if you're reading this, Lemongrass peeps. 

Food and service is always consistently good and I enjoy making a stop here every time I stay at Vdara/Aria.

I read many of the reviews on Lemongrass and now that I have dined there, I understand cause for the dissenting reviews (noting point losses mostly in service inconsistency and bland food.) I have not tried other Thai restaurants in the Las Vegas area yet. But, I enjoy Thai food and had many opportunities to have really great Thai cuisine. 

Both dishes I had (chicken wing appetizer and drunken noodle entree) were recommendations from the restaurant to be among their "best". But, if you've tasted good Thai, you will agree that the flavors are comparatively bland and the texture is not ideal in some dishes. 

The service wasn't well coordinated, but I prefer being checked on by several servers asking/offering the same items to me then to have no one check on me.

I rounded up and gave Lemongrass 3 stars rather than 2.5, mostly because on a 5star rating, they barely made crossing over the halfway point. Honestly, 4 stars and above should be reserved for restaurants that are far better in class than their great competition, however, Lemongrass is not at that point yet - I hope they get there.

Up shot: I did like the mango sticky rice dessert. I think the interior is very nice and most importantly, the staff are very kind. But save the sticky rice, it's not a location I'd bring guests to who love Thai food. For as attractive as the restaurant is, I wish they invested more in the food.

Conveniently located directly next to the elevators to our suite@Aria.. 

Of all the items we ordered.. I would say my favorite was the tamarind ribeye steak.. it was very juicy and moist.. and the tamarind dip was a really good touch

3.5 stars..

came back with my BFF. They offer Dim Sum for lunch now. There' sonly 1 Dim Sum cart goes around the dining room. Limited choices, & we ordered:

- Xiu mai - mediocre,
- Fung Chao - chicken feet - no taste to it,
- Hao Cao - shrimp dumpling - wasn't even hot.
- Schezwan beef noodle soup
- Thai Fried Rice - the best one of all.

I was surprised that it was supposed to be a Thai restaurant, but the menu offers from Vietnamese to Chinese, Thai to Singaporean.

Service was good, but the food wasn't, even we were hung over!

This is hands down the best "fine dining" thai restaurant that I've ever been to.  It was conveniently located inside our hotel (The Aria) and was priced pretty modestly.

We started off with their awesome prawn  rolls, shared a chillean seabass, a lobster fried rice(was on their specials menu) and duck penang curry. All of these entrees were amazing and they made them with just the right amount of spicyness.  We asked for a 4/5.... and we were sweating ever so slightly...PERFECT :).

We ordered every single drink on the cocktail menu, all of which were awesome.  We opted not to get dessert, but our waiter was really nice and bought us a fried banana on the house.

Thanks for the lovely experience!

We came here for restaurant week and I am so pleased that I did. We had lunch and cannot say enough about how delicious it was. This was not my 1st time here. 

The service is fast and very friendly. It started with a lovely soup with mushrooms and vegetables that was mildly spicy for me and more spicy for my friend. Our appetizers were the chicken and beef satay skewers and they were amazing. For my main meal, I had the Panang curry chicken. I asked for it to be as mild as possible. From a scale of 1 to 10, I asked for one. The meal was so good. It was not spicy which I loved, but it could have been made very spicy for someone who enjoys that. My friend ordered the shrimp pad Thai and asked that it be spicier. They honored that! The beauty of this restaurant is that I like Thai food a lot, but I am unable to tolerate very spicy food. This restaurant always successfully manages to create delicious meals that are either very mild or very spicy, depending on how one likes it. Dessert was a scoop of mango sorbet which was very nice on the palate.
The prices are reasonable, the restaurant is beautiful, the food is delicious, and the service is always friendly. Highly recommended!

Large generous portions, waiter was slack and slow.. Asked for tea coffee 3 times before we got refills., Food not spicy as requested. Sesame chicken was good however top layer was not hot. not a repeat for this one
Very nice wait staff.  Good food and quick service.  We ordered take out so we can enjoy it in our hotel room.  Very nice ambiance too.

Well. I just don't even know what to say. The hostess said a ten minute wait, but the place was empty. Then when we finally did get a seat by walking over and sitting at the bar, they didn't have any dim sum on the menu. I only came here for dim sum after seeing the advertisements ...all of which were pictures of dim sum. Apparently they only serve it from 11-3 on Friday-Sunday. So why on earth is EVERY advertisement of a food you don't serve...? Go home lemongrass, you're drunk.
Food was great.  Steam rice was extra- which  is lame. Service was slow - but that is the case at most places in vegas. Overall a great experience.

This restaurant is one of my Vegas favorites. At my most recent visit, my friend and I sat at the bar and ordered diner. It was lively with a great atmosphere. In a previous visit, my group ate in the dining area - excellent service there too.
The food is so tasty. In true Thai fashion, the heat is about flavor - not just hot. The drinks are so tasty and strong. The crab fried rice is delicious.
The staff is professional and friendly.

Very representative of the situation my wife and I often find ourselves in: it is hard to find good food on vacation. Lemongrass offers classically mediocre Thai food, plus you will get a 1 hour wait for absolutely no reason. Our meal: fried spring rolls ($10) these were clearly straight out of the freezer, no flavor, soggy vegetables; pho reeked of cinnamon ($15); Singapore Noodles Stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, curry powder ($18) this was quite good and very spicy, earning Lemongrass 3 instead of 2 stars.

Poor food, poor service, long wait. Do not make a reservation; I would suggest trying a different restaurant.

Lemongrass was very good.  Classier and more than twice the price of what we'd get for something similar in LA, but the cuts of meat are nicer, the waitstaff is very pro and attentive, and the ingredients are top notch.

However, the tom kha was EXTREMELY spicy.  Like, Thai spicy.  As in, we asked for medium (I've been to thailand twice and can handle some VERY spicy food) and we were served something we could barely eat.  It was vert tasty, so I downed it, but had to pay with a tummy ache later.  That said, most Thai places take the really spicy Thai peppers, split them with the side of a knife, and put them in for flavor.  Lemongrass seemed to have ground up the peppers iN the soup, which is kind of a no-no, as it was just WAY too hot, and killed the flavor, so we had runny noses and fire-burned tastebuds.

The Shanghai rice noodles, although not Thai, were delicious, and perfect, and beautiful form the tri-colored bell peppers.  VERY nice, good food (save the crazy spiciness of the soup), and kind of what you'd expect from an upscale casino restaurant.  Not cheap, but good, and it was the only place open for lunch at 3 o'clock.

Went here on Sunday night for late post-dinner dining after super blood moon gazing BBQ w friends. 

I was looking for something Asiany w broth, and Blossom, the Chinese restaurant, seemed a little over the top and pricy given that we had already eaten dinner at the BBQ. 

The decor was nice enough in the standard high end Las Vegas/ century city way, but gave a masculine, impersonal, corporate vibe, what with all the wood/ropes on the ceiling and walls and oversized lantern-looking lighting. The restaurant was dimly lit but was not romantic. It didn't even look Asian -- it could have just as easily served hamburgers and martini. 

Food:  we ordered Chilean sea bass as per yelp recommendation and it was delicious. A chunk of fish filet was panko breaded and deep fried, and served drenched with thick garlicky sweet and sour sauce, with sliced green onion heaped on top. The green onion strips seemed fried as they were crunchy but was not oily. Not sure how they did that.  Hubby did not like it and thought that green onion strips just tasted hard, but I liked the light crunch. I would definitely recommend this dish. 

We also ordered Mongolian beef noodle soup, which had tendon and Bok Choy. The soup was just okay, improved much by a generous dollop of hot sauce, because hot sauce makes everything better. Beef was "dark" meat ( don't know the name of the cut but I accidentally bought it at a Korean grocery store before so am familiar with it). This cut has a lot of blood in the meat so it is dark in color and has a subtle metallic flavor from all the iron in the meat. Tendon was weirdly slimy -- I like my tendon firm but this was more slimy fatty type which is decidedly off-putting. Noodle was fresh. I ate all the Bok choy, some beef, some noodles, and all the broth so My craving was satisfied, but would not order the same dish again.

Yikes. I should have paid more attention to the Yelp reviews on this place, but there aren't many sit-down lunch options at Aria and we were on a pre-meeting time crunch. The other nearby option was the French pastry place with the pre-made sandwiches laid out in a display case... But we're fans of Thai food and figured: "how bad can it be?" 

Well, apparently it can be much worse than we thought. We started with the vegetarian spring rolls and the prawns (which our waiter assured us was "the best appetizer on the menu"). The spring rolls could have come from any cheap hole-in-the-wall Chinese place I've ever been to. I wish they had been better because they ended up being the only thing I ate for lunch. I'm told the prawns were okay, but if they were "the best appetizer," my dining companion commented that the other options must be pretty scary.

For entrees we decided to try the pad Thai, chicken satay and some vegetable fried rice. I kid you not - the pad Thai tasted like dish water. The fried rice had no sauce, and was basically white rice with little squares of carrot and onion in it. The satay came with peanut sauce, and while I had never before met a peanut sauce I didn't like, this one was awful. It was bland, noticeably lacking in sweetness (which would have enhanced the otherwise-absent flavor), and quite honestly just not worth the calories.  

We had no complaints about the service or ambiance, but in a city filled with so many great restaurants this one definitely belongs at the bottom of the dining list.

Cost effective and delicious.  Arrived late and was told wait was 45 minutes then got lucky when one of the few chairs at the bar opened up.  Duby (the bartender) was fun to chat with while she was making drinks.  The waiter suggested the Green Curry (chicken, Thai eggplant, and Thai basil) and Three Cups Chicken.  Both were good dishes!  I like spicy food but the server suggested a four (on a 10-point scale) which ended up being the perfect level of heat.  I'll definitely return!

11/2016 UPDATE - I had dinner at Lemongrass last month and basically ate the same dishes family style with friends.  Although everything was consistent with my first experience part of of me wished they had improved on the dishes in the last several years but alas it was basically the same.

It is with great regret that I have to give Lemongrass only 2 stars.  This resto nails the sexy asian vibe, with its stunning minimalist decor.  Service is also v. good -- with folks coming in to check up on diners at regular intervals.  But, no amount of service and decor can make up for so-so food.... Now, I can try to blame it on one of my dining companions, who insisted that the spice factor for all the dishes be a 1 on scale of 10.... but, non-spicy food can still have flavor.  While the salmon spring rolls had a nice crisp to them, throughout the rest of the meal (which included shrimp fried rice, steamed cod, cashew chicken and tiger prawns), I kept thinking: this is dressed up Panda Express.... in a tuxedo.  Seriously. Entrees at over $25 for sub-par food?? Nope.  Never again.  Hopefully, food gets better soon...

These guys totally deserve 5 stars for food and service. Everything was awesome. We got the Tom ka soup that was amazing, dumpling and spring roll pretty average. The main dishes hit the spot. We got the beef fried rice, sesame chicken, cashew chicken and a couple other dishes that were all great. Definitely will be going back next time.

My boyfriend and I stopped in recently while walking around Aria on a Sunday afternoon.  My boyfriend wanted me to try his new favorite dish, Pho.  I ordered the Chicken Pho and even though I was feeling sick that day, I ate the entire bowl.  My boyfriend has become a sort of "Pho conoisseur" and he said that was exactly how Pho should taste. I loved it and unfortunately, coming back to the East Coast, I haven't found better (although I've been told to go to my hometown neighborhood of South Philly on Washington Ave).

My boyfriend ordered some sort of Curry Chicken dish and the Tom Kha Ga soup.  He loved every last bit of both.

This will be the first restaurant we go to on our next trip out to Vegas.

P.S. 4 out of 5 stars only because after our waiter brought us our food, we didn't see him again until we were ready for the check.  Usually I wouldn't mind being left alone but being sick the day we went, I really wanted more green tea.

Nicely located in one of the best casinos on the strip. It also has nice ambiance and almost all the time, there was no waiting. They are located near a very expensive mall and in an expensive hotel so they are pricey for a Thai food place. 

We were a group of four and we were well tended to our needs with courtesy and respect. I would like to point out that place has nice seating arrangement for groups and couples alike. I had a curry dish with rice and it was delicious. Everyone on our table enjoyed their food. The food is very spicy so you want to be careful with your spice number when you are ordering. 

I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a very nice place to hangout and get some good Thai food at the same time.
Pad Thai is wonderful. The Thai soup was just what the Dr ordered for s cold and Jose the bartender was very friendly and gave great service.

Very nice place, but only decent Thai Food.

First off I would like to state that I am happy a Thai Place exists on the strip.  For that reason I think Lemongrass is awesome.  However, the decor falls way above the food.

I came here late on a Friday night with my friend who gets out of work after 11.  I mostly picked off his food as I had already eaten.  I tried the veg rolls, which were tasty but not amazing and the mango sticky rice.  Both were good but only mediocar.  Looking over the menu they had few vegetarian friendly options and mostly meaty dishes.  It seemed that rather than stick traditional thai style food the menu deviated a bit.  I would come again, but only if provoked

The decor is gorgeous.  High ceilings and rich brown flavors.  If your going on a date, and looking for someplace nice, classy and romantic.  I think you would be safe picking lemongrass.

My friend and I were craving Thai on our last night in Vegas so we came here. We had the chicken wings, fish cakes, papaya salad, and pad thai. We also had Thai iced te which wasn't too sweet. Just right.. Everything was so tasty and delicious. The ambience here is classy and upscale. The service here is great and so was the food.

We were staying at the Aria and I was craving for Asian food so we decided to try this place out instead of having to venture outside the hotel. It's supposed to be a Thai restaurant from what I understand but they have blended chinese fusion to it as well. I was surprised when I saw a Dimsum cart pull up next to our table but I was equally surprised by how authentic it all tasted. We ordered a good mix of thai and chinese dishes and were not disappointed. They say that you know it's a great Asian restaurant if you actually see Asian patrons in it and trust me, there was a fair number of us out there. The staff was friendly and attentive but the price is of course, was Vegas style, for something I feel I can get at a local joint for less money. Highly recommended for when you're looking for a great eats without having to leave the resort.

The Aria hotel is beautiful, and so is this Thai restaurant located on the ground floor of the Aria. Although not blow-your-mind Thai food, this is a safe option for lunch.

+2 stars for the ambience and being in the hotel I stayed at
+1 for the decent but not great Thai food
-2 for the not fresh jellyfish and bad value (expensive for what it is)

Our order:
The penang curry with duck was WAY too heavy in consistency... Too much coconut milk and no depth of flavor. 
The drunken noodle was quite good! We got it with seafood.
Thai iced tea met the standard.
Jellyfish in chili oil: Meh, not recommended. Not fresh.

Coming from SGV and SF, I was a bit underwhelmed by this place.  Although it is decorated to be fancier, being in Vegas.  

Service: This is the better part, they were friendly and suggested wines or alcoholic drinks.  

Food:  Nothing that stands out too much, although we did do the restaurant week for Vegas, some portions seemed to be small but definitely nothing special.

I love Thai food and have been there over 50X. I wanted desperately for this to be a good Thai outlet, but I was sorely disappointed. The dishes are very uneven. The satay and Tom Yum Ghoong soup was excellent as were the satay. The chicken breast dish I had was breast meat that was over battered and the meat so dry I could not chew it or swallow it. My partshrimp entrée was good, but not excellent. The mango sticky rice desert was good. The fried bananas were terrible. The menu and cooking seems to be dominated by Chinese influence. May be part of the reason it was lacking. Service was good through the entrees and then everyone disappeared. Had to grab someone from another section to get desert and the check at the same time. Really wish I could have had better things to say.

Love Aria.  Best hotel on the strip.  However, the eatery... didn't follow suit. This place is bit expensive for thai and what you get.  Service was just okay, they seemed unorganized.  Maybe cause they're fairly new, but employees seemed unsure of everything.  Got alot of blank looks when I asked a question.  "Can I eat in the Bar?" Blank stare.  "Can I still order off the Early Dinner Menu on Weekends?" Blank stare.  "Wheres the bathroom?" ..... Blank stare. 

Skip the early dinner, btw. Too pricey.  Just order off the regular menu.  Or go to Serranos.  That place is awesome.  Service and food are on point there.

Not bad for Vegas.  We enjoyed a variety of different dishes here, although I was not impressed with the silver noodles.  The Tom Yum Goong was good, and the rice dumpling dessert was excellent.  Our servers could have been more relaxed, but we had no complaints.  If you're at ARIA and looking for a decent, casual meal that won't break the bank, I recommend Lemongrass.  They are also open throughout the day.

Basil beef was pretty sweet, sauce was thick and had very little kick to it. I eat that as my go to dish in Thai restaurants and this was not one of the best. Service was pretty slow, not terrible, but could have been sharper. Wife and friends enjoyed theirs more than me. Nice decor and ambience though, just not the nicest food.

Pro: it's open late. The food definitely tasted good and the waiter was very friendly.

Cons: EXPENSIVE! I mean I know it is Las Vegas and everything comes a little bit pricy. But the entrees are pretty expensive already, then you have to order a portion of rice. And they only have one kind of rice, no other choices at all, what really surprised me given the location and type of restaurant.

What a nice place to eat at! Came here by recommendation and paying it forward. Decor matched the restaurant theme perfectly. Appetizers were good. For my main dish, I had the Curry Dungeness Crab at a level 7 (1-10 spicy). I was sweating a bit, but enjoyed it so much! Dish was huge and overall experience great. I go back there every time I am in Vegas!

Did not try too many items as our shrimp mousse appetizer and soft shell crab salad were filling and very good.  The mango for the mango and sticky rice could have been sweeter.  Prices were reasonable for Vegas and most of the other customers were Asian.  Service was fast and efficient.

ambiance - superb. loved their decor
Food - Good. not the best in town but not bad either
service - Superb. our waiter was very helpful and attentive
over all experience - Great!

Not bad! Really good fried rice with seafood I forgot which one, the one without the pork for sure. I like their orange chicken. They have dim sum and other Asian food there'd too not just thai. I would come back..
Was a bit weary to eat here after reading some not so great reviews. But we enjoyed it very much. Green papaya salad, a favorites was one of the best ever. Service was pleasant. Ambience soothing.

This is not Thai. If you go to this place with the mind set of not eating Thai then you might find it satisfying. The only thing that is Thai, spicy hot, they make it spicy hot where your tongue is buring only if choose so. 
Decor of the place is nice. Service is fine.
Really tasty.  This was some of the best Thai food I have had in Vegas, and there is a lot of great Thai food.  I would absolutely come here again should I find myself on the strip.
Love this place! Its very pricey for your usual Thai restaurant but the service is awesome! Ambiance is great! Food is really, really good!

I should have gave them higher rating but after I finished my dishes and got back to my hotel... I went straight to the toilet and... My stomach did not feel so good. I think maybe because the dish was too oily. The taste is ok. We ordered stir-fried mushroom over rice and yellow curry(I had this one)

I was hungry when I started, impressed the prices weren't catastrophic.
Fried veggie rolls were good. 
I left full which was the goal. For asian food in LV do this if you're starving and too lazy to look around. If I was in Aria I'd go here for sure for convenience. 

If you like super spicy food just tell them, they'll make it spicy. 

Servers were nice.

I love love love Thai food! This is not my absolute favorite because it is not authentic Thai food as you would have at a hole in the wall but it is very good. It has a different taste to, not as bold as the authentic Thai, however, still very good. I ended up falling asleep on the table here as I was very drunk lol.

The quality of food is unfortunately not worth it's ambiance. The surrounding is nice and is the only reason this is getting 2 stars. The food was very mediocre. Has the tom yum soup...chicken and mashed on was very chewy and soup was over the top lemony. Also had the basil chicken and chicken was again very chewy...low quality. And I've honestly never had brown rice taste as it did at this place.
We stopped by for a late dinner and were promptly seated and served.  All of the food and drinks were on point, but it was very pricey for a Thai meal.

Duck curry, oh my god! Insanely delicious! A must try, im not a fan of curry but is the right amount of curry and spiciness and the duck nicely tender. 

Service very helpful and really know how to pair the food with wine. Not expensive for been on the Strip and specially at the Aria. 

Definitely will come back.

Over priced and rude waitresses.... Entrees don't come with rice- $3 for a side of white/ $4 for brown rice.. Who eats curry without rice? I gave 2 stars because the pad Thai was good... But everything else was pretty bad! I Will not go again.
Omg seafood drunken noodle here is so good. They could spice it however you like. I crave this place a lot. Anything is good here. There is a wait.

Service awesome, decor fabulous but food is not up to expectation. We ordered vegetable fried rice  and steam cod. Presentation was really good but food is below average. For the price they charge they should do more authentic taste instead of going fusion.

First, we are Thai. This is the first Thai restaurant ever where I drank a martini before dinner and coffee after. This is the first Thai restaurant I've ever seen where people were offered and served champagne with their meal. Wine is horrid with spicy Thai food, but champagne is heaven. I'm glad the prices are high because it keeps out all the casino riff-raft and street sleaze that's all too common on the strip. We wanted to see if this restaurant could make decent traditional Thai food so we ordered some standards like tom yum goong; green curry; and white fish. The tom yum came with huge shrimpers although it lacked a good spicy kick. We requested our green curry be made with tofu and they did it. The green curry was very good, but again lacked a little kick. The white fish was great-very tasty and served with the traditional nam prik. All in all the food was very good, and very traditional. The wait staff were all Asian, but only a couple were Thai. Our waitress luckily was Thai so our family could speak Thai to her. My pet peave was piqued at this place because many of the farang patrons ate their Thai food with chop sticks. Thai people don't eat like Chinese. We use a fork and spoon for most things. We might use chop sticks if were eating a noodle soup. So put your chop sticks down when in a Thai restaurant and use a spoon and fork!!! We recommend this place. Good service. Good Thai food. If Vegas strip prices bother you, you may want to ask yourself what the hell are you doing on the strip to begin with????? You've gotta order champagne and satay. It goes great together.

The food was mediocore,at best. You're paying for the loud ambience, which is getting a bit repetitive at each of the restaurants on the Strip. 

The chicken wings were the saving glory of the meal, as they were well seasoned and well cooked. The green curry was pretty soupy, and didnt have any other flavor other than the coconut. The basil meat I was most disappointed by, because you could not even taste the basil that was in the dish.

Party of 4 for early lunch. Ordered 4 dishes and one  appetizer. Spring rolls great. 2 of the 4 dishes were very good- two of the 4 were so so (bland) and we did not finish those. Chicken cashew should be fabulous here- but it was not notable and the meat cuts were not appetizing- kindof odd shaped with firm texture. When she dropped the check she noticed empty glasses and asked it we wanted refills- well not now... Beef satay is very very tasty!!! Overall expected more fun and flavor for such a prime location and price.

lemongrass at aria i thought was a great find. its hard to find a good fancy asian restaurant nowadays. their decor was really cool. very modern just like the rest of the hotel. there are private rooms as well if u have a large party.

their menu is straight to the point. satays, curries, noodles and main entrees. we had the satays for our appetizer. it was really good. each order comes with four. we also had the gyoza. pretty standard. and their fried prawns were amazing. we did our entrees family style. we had the steak with tamarind sauce, and omg it was incredible. one of the best steaks ive had wc is weird because i didnt expect it from an asian place. we also had the singapore noodles. soo good! and their chicken curry. they have the usual spicy scale. we got ours at number 3 and it was pretty darn spicy. i can only imagine their number 10. 

we didnt get desserts as we were going to china poblano next door for that but i glanced at the menu and they had pretty good choices too. they had mango sticky rice wc sounded really good.  the prices were actually not as bad as i thought. although they had  110 dollar lobster dishes that im sure are incredible. i think its worth the money as u are getting a more formal and nicer dining experience at an asian restaurant with good quality food and great ambience.

Service is slow.  Tables and booths are uncomfortable to sit in... but the place looks nice and the food is really good.  Tom Kha Chicken was probably the best coconut soup I've had (something I usually order at most Thai restaurants) and, oh man... the yellow chicken curry.... wow.  We couldn't stop talking about how tasty it was.  Mmm.

If you're in the mood for Thai, you'll like Lemongrass.  Just don't expect great service.

I'm surprised the reviews aren't higher here.  I've been eating at Lemongrass since it opened and have always had a good experience (although I don't love spicy food).  The atmosphere is nice, the watermelon caipirinha is amazing, and the shrimp fried rice is a great choice if you don't want anything spicy.  We recently ordered the banana dessert and it was good, but not good enough to order again.  

I do have to say that on our last trip, we decided to sit in the dining room (we usually sit at the bar) and it took us a long time to be greeted.  We ended up moving to the bar and had the usual good service we'd come to expect.  Juby and Anthony (?) at the bar are great and always remember us.

We ended up at Lemongrass for a late dinner since it's one of the only restaurants open past 10:30p in Aria.

Situated towards the back of the hotel on the casino level, Lemongrass sits next to the Baccarat room & Blossom restaurant. Lemongrass has a relaxing vibe, both beautiful and modern inside - lots of dark woods, sleek booths, and eye-catching, large lantern lightings.

We ordered the Tom Yam Talay soup to start. Lemongrass ranks spiciness as mild, medium, hot, and very hot. We chose our soup to be medium/hot and it came out very spicy!! We love the heat but wow that soup was difficult to enjoy. Either way, the spicy, creamy broth was filled with all types of delicious seafood & had a great mix of lemongrass and ginger flavors. The abalone mushrooms were so tender and yummy too!

We were not too hungry so we decided to share the Singapore Noodles.  Wow, these servings are large! Surprisingly we weren't asked our desired spice level for this dish, and actually found it a bit bland. While we weren't particularly impressed with the noodles--it wasn't better or worse than your typical Thai hole-in-the-wall spot--the portion size is perfect for big eaters who want to dine at a fancier restaurant without breaking the bank.

Overall Lemongrass ranks at 3.5 stars. We weren't really blown away by the food but the ambiance is very beautiful and cozy.

Loved this restaurant. The best part was the lobster satay a little on the expensive side ($24.00) but worth it. Everything was cooked perfectly and tasted great. Will visit again next time I'm in Vegas

It was just ok! I expected more. More value, more flavor, for the Tasting Menu $59 +$29 for pairings (which had little alcohol in them). The Thai restaurant in San Diego in our neighborhood has better flavor. Aria advertises this place as the only Thai place on the Strip....well...thy best kick up their game as the #1 spot is up for grabs.

We asked for spicy,..it was not. 

The Chilli sauce condiment bowl was empty. We brought this to the attention of the waiter. Bowl was refilled, not washed or cleaned prior with the old Chilli still dried to the wall of the container. 

The Chicken Salad tasted bad and merely looked like it was boiled and processed through a meat grinder! ..it was bad and something I wouldn't feed my beagle.

We wanted to order a drink with Ginger - they were out of ginger. 

We announced a special occasion - they forgot. 

Flavor wise - it was all mediocre

...I woke up the next day thinking about how bad it was. I will call the restaurant today and suggest management sit under cover, and eat the tasting menu. As Gordon Ramsey would say to the chef "did you taste it?"

I've been in Vegas for almost two months and this place has restored my hope for good restaurants off the strip. If you're a fan of spice and Thai this is the place for you! Atmosphere: A+, service A+, food A++. I really loved it! I got the Thai Basil Chicken and side I can't speak for the other plates, I highly recommend it!

Oh my goodness, I loved this restaurant! 

My friend and I split one of the Pad Thai dishes, just to have some food in our stomachs (there wasn't a lot of extra room for full stomach in our outfits... if you know what I mean...).

We both ordered the Pink Leopard to drink, that drink was AMAZING. 

There was a very short wait, so we grabbed a glass of prosecco down the hall, and they called me when our table was ready. Really great Saturday night dinner.

We ended up here after my boyfriend's father was craving Asian & we wanted something on the cheaper end of Vegas dining. We also love Thai food and are frequent patrons of Thai restaurants. This place still is Strip-priced, (expect $16+ for fried rice or chow mein), but was decent for where we were.

The atmosphere is nice with dark booths and dim lighting. The service was friendly, but were not as attentive as I would have liked. 

I ordered the vegetarian pad see-ew, which comes with flat rice noodles, broccoli, egg, & tofu. Simple. It also had a green leaf next to it on the menu indicating one of the vegetarian options- which I loved and appreciated. Regardless, when I got my meal (& I was so ravenous I just dug in), my 1st bite was a mix of white tofu & white CHICKEN!!! UGH!!! Manners & impressing the boyfriend's parents pushed aside, I immediately spit up the contents in my napkin. I have been a vegetarian for 17 years now, that was absolutely disgusting & such an inappropriate mistake for a restaurant to make. Also, why on earth would the kitchen staff put in two proteins?! They clearly charge you double for adding extra protein, & this was one of the specially marked vegetarian entrees. Normally I inspect my meals just in case, but I was just so hungry & trusting... It took a long time to get someone's attention to make it right, & they had to remake my dish while I sat there hungry watching everyone else eat. We were also in a hurry that night as we had after dinner plans. When I finally got my new dish, it had no meat, but it was much drier than the original dish. It also did not taste Thai, or like pad see ew, it was like regular Chinese chow fun. Very disappointing. 

The other people in our party ordered the basil beef fried rice, shrimp curry, beef chow fun, & chicken curry, & each enjoyed their meals. I would still recommend this place if you are craving Asian cuisine in Vegas, but beware, vegetarians!

The decor of this place is amazing: I'd give it 5 stars.
But when it comes to the food, I am not so sure. I am a Pad See Ew addict, and I've been eating it EVERYWHERE, so for $18 a plate, I was expecting to eat the best Pad See Ew of my life. It was definitely good, but it wasn't the BEST. The portion however was of a good size, and the service was nice. 
The location is a bit further from the main strip, but then again, it's closer than most other Thai restaurants in Vegas!

Three of us dined here on 5-6-2014: restaurant not busy. We ordered cashew chicken, mushroom and asparagus, bok choy, cucumber salad, and oolong tea. Also brown rice. Food delicious and seasoned nicely. Server excellent; only reason for less than five stars is bus service cleared all utensils before we finished the meal and kept taking plates before we were done. 

I'm from Chicago, so I am accustomed to high dining prices, but Wow Vegas takes the extreme pricing to a whole other level. 100.00 high, but food delicious. Waiter did warn me three times that their Jasmine green tea was 25.00 glass.  I skipped it but I was curious what a 25.00 cup of tea tastes like?
A must destination spot on the strip, great food and beautiful ambiance. We suggest the Tom Kha, Phad Thai, and Curry plate

My go to place whenever I'm in Vegas and I'm there pretty often.  Inside the Aria Hotel so you would expect the prices to be a lot pricier but it's very reasonable with good size portions and good food.  Pretty consistent every time I have been here.  Obviously it's not the best Thai food I've had but pretty good and service is usually very good!!

We ate here last night with friends and had a lovely dinner. Luckily we went with someone from Thailand, so they could guide us through the menu. The ambiance was lovely and our server was more than attentive. The lobster skewers with the Peanut Sauce was excellent and easily one of my favorite dishes. We also had the Drunken Noodles which were very spicy, but very tasty. My top dish was the Chicken Curry. A definite must have. All in all a good Thai restaurant in a beautiful hotel.

The best way to sum up this place in one word is:  OVERPRICED!  Dined here for dinner with some friends on Saturday 6/25/11.  Since the Aria is so big, it was hard to find this place.  When we finally did find this restaurant, we sat down and looked at the menu.  I was shocked to see Thai food so expensive and so overpriced.  Can you believe they were trying to sell pad thai for like $16??!  I was shocked.  I can find better tasting pad thai for less than half the price they were selling their's for.  I ended up just ordering a bowl of their wonton soup for $14.  Yes, $14!!  There was nothing great about it.  The wontons were good, but the overall soup tasted like it came out of a Top Ramen bag.  Totally disappointing.  One of my friends ordered the pepper shrimp which was good, but a bit on the salty side.  Their pineapple fried rice was good I do have to say.  

My advice is  save yourself some $$$ and dine somewhere else.  Personally, I like Archie's Thai Restaurant on Flamingo.  Food is great and affordable.  Or if you don't want to that, try YELPing a few places.  :)

The restaurant is gorgeous, the food was amazing and our server was incredibly helpful and attentive. It was definitely a bit pricey, but totally worth it!!! Warning - they charge $12.00 for Young Coconut. Yikes!!!

Could not have a reservation or walk in for dinner so I ordered takeout.

Yam Ta Krai 3/5
Spicy seafood salad. Large shrimp and scallops. A good value at $16. Level 3 (medium) is pretty spicy for me.

Shredded Pork with Dried Bean Curd 3/5
Spicy.

This is one of the most beautiful restaurants I've ever seen.

If I could feast on beauty, my taste buds and my tummy would have been deeply satiated.

Do you like gloop? Do you like your food swimming in such deep sauce that you have a hard time determining what you're eating? Do you like gobs of fatty sauce? Then you might like Lemongrass!

Pork rice. Thought it was fried rice, but it wasn't. It would have been tasty if this were steam table Chinese.

Fried rice. Loved the deep fried shitake. But the rest of it was greasy.

Steak and gloop. I'm sure that's not what it was called on the menu. This was a tiny portion of beef, utterly drowned in a peanut sauce that made my arteries harden just looking at it. 

Duck and gloop. I don't think it was called this either, but again, the tiny portion of duck was drowned in so much sauce. The dish was probably as many calories as a human should eat in a week. 

Sesame chicken and gloop. This was a sweet and sour type sauce with a lot of sugar and gloop.

If you like your food "smothered" in sauce to the point where there is nothing but gobs of fat in your mouth, you'll probably love this place.

Such a beautiful restaurant, surely deserves better food.

Wanted something quick and this recommended we order the chicken wings and the Phad See Ew with chicken. The chicken wings were ok and the Phad See Ew had no flavor at all. Very disappointing considering the price point of the meals.
Always great food with low price. Once you eat here you will never like Thai somewhere else.

Excellent Thai food, best I've ever had. We started w/ the Spicy Asian Cucumber and the Potstickers. Light, refreshing, different. Then moved on to the Panang Curry duck (red curry)... outstanding! Creamy red sauce over savory duck breast. Phad Thai Goong, they asked how spicy? (Scale 1-10) we went with 10... It's "Thai" hot... very flavorful, slow building, warmth... It's real phad thai.

The Mai Tai's are nicely mixed as well.

my bf and i decided to change up the scene a little for our 3 year anniversary dinner..we usually go to blossom's (which is right next to lemongrass). we just wanted to try something new and different.

lemongrass is thai cuisine resturant and is located in aria next to the barracat area in a hidden hallway. i had called beforehand to make reservations to reserve private booth and a lil early bday dessert for my boyfriend. the host who anwered my call was a bit of a bitch when i asked about these not so difficult accomodations...either she gave me that long "ooookayyyyyy..." as a reply or not even a thank you...who said it? i said thank you..i wish i didnt have to though.

we arrived there a little early since we were staying at the vdara next door so it was small walk to lemongrass. i told the host i had reservations and that we were 15mins early but she immediately seated us in a booth i had asked for and our server was great/polite/attentive. he was def great in customer service, wished i got his name! the aura of lemongrass was interesting..it was pretty dark than i expected it to be from looking at it from the front of the resturant.

my bf and i ordered their chicken satay as an apetitizer and damn it was so authentic and delicious! im thai, so they def got it started on the right foot! their thai teas were amazingly great and again authentic. our main entrees were the rib eye steak with tamarind sauce and basil beef fried rice. we both shared the entrees and it was amazingly YUUUMMYY!  the rib eye is something i enjoyed the most and would reccommend.  the basil fried rice was surprisingly spicy..esp for myself..i loveeeee spicy food so that was a lot coming from me.

later our server came to surprise my bf with their mango and sweet rice dessert witha  candle in it. guess what, it was complimentary! it is originally $7 but since it was a bday dessert they gave it to us for free!

overall, this is a much cheaper alternative to blossom but still a great place to eat and get full...also to have a nice private lil dinner.

Made reservation 3 days prior .  Walked in 30 minutes early.  Blank stare.  Started with one server.  Changed to another mid way without being told.  Asked for two checks and received one.  Shall I continue?  

Will never return.  Too many great restaurants to choose from in Las Vegas.

Although this place is listed as a Thai restaurant,  it is more Asian Fusion as they have a mix of Thai and Chinese food.  I ended up ordering the Tom Kha Chicken Soup and the Yellow Curry, both them were ordered at a 8 (out of 10) for a spice level.

The Tom Kha Chicken soup was pretty large and was enough to feed 2-3 people.  The flavors were wonderful and there was plenty of chicken pieces.  The only thing that was new to me was these funny looking mushrooms that they used,  they had a purple top, but their bottoms and stems were more of a white/beige color.  

The yellow curry was great as well, but there were a few pieces of potatoes that were undercooked.   The slickness of the dish was more on the mild side even tho I ordered it at a very hot level.  This dish was also large enough to share with a friend or two.

I took off a couple of stars because the service was pretty bad.  When I walked in, they didn't have any tables available and so they offered to seat me at the bar.  I grabbed one of the smaller tables beside the bar, sat down and within a few minutes I had my menu.  Then it took about another 10-15 minutes before the waiter came by to take my order.  When I was finished with my meal,  they came by took away my dishes and asked if there was anything else,  I said no and they went away.  Expecting to receive my bill, I ended up waiting another 15 mins before they came back with my bill.  So dinner at a place like this should take about 30-40 mins,  it ended up taking over an hour.  And it was not that busy in the bar area, so I couldn't understand why the lack of attention.

This place is also pretty expensive, for my 2 dishes, a Thai iced tea, and a small plate of rice(yes it was extra) my meal came out to about $33.

Several good reviews on here, but my one experience was not.  Food was mediocre Thai.  I understand the modern fusion twist, but I have had dive Thai places much better than this.  Shared several dishes among companions, like drunken noodles, salmon, chicken satay, etc.  Food was not good value for the price $.  For what I consider one of the newer casinos in Vegas, the service was too slow.  Left the restaurant hungry.  I'm all for second chances, but with so many other choices in Vegas why would I come back?

Lemongrass is my favorite Thai restaurant in Las Vegas.  Located at ARIA Resort & Casino.  Menu is extensive and mid range for pricing.  Had lunch today and enjoyed the Chicken Sate with peanut sauce and marinated cucumber salad for starter.  Always a favorite - yellow curry chicken with brown rice, chicken pad thai and the soft shell crab friend rice.  Were a table of 6 and shared family-style.  Service was friendly. Great choice with friends from out of town.

Flavors have great potential, but falls short of excellence.  My dish was dan dan noodles with overcooked noodles-meh.  One friend had drunken noodles which was good.  We had excellent spring rolls.  Our soup was an incredibly tasting tom kha; however,  large chunks (but not large enough to pick out) of lemongrass and makrut (generally considered inedible ) were left in the soup.  The final dish was a great tasting curry.  Six out of ten was too spicy and we are in to spice.  On our visit, it seemed that there is potential for a really great meal here.

I don't think I ever need to come back here again. This place is over priced and portions are teeny. I ordered the soft shell crab salad ($25) and while it was filled with yummy soft shell crabs, it was too spicy and I finished it in about 4 bites. No kidding. We also ordered the lobster salad and steak salad and those were good too but also very tiny! The decor is nice but a bit too modern and the seating is awkward. I guess the prices are not bad for Vegas but unfortunately, Lemongrass is just not up to par.

This place has really nice decor. We just wanted to visit Aria since it was new and stopped here for early dinner around 5 PM. The service was very good and they were very attentive. They even asked us for chop sticks!! Good. I can't eat Asian food without chop sticks, I guess I'm Asian lol. 

The food was very ordinary. Not worth the overpriced price we paid for for regular Thai food. We ordered the Tom Kha soup with Chicken. Beef skew with some sauce for starter. We had Green Curry and Pad Thai for entree. The Tom Kha was pretty good, and the portion was huge. They gave us a lot, it could serve four people. The Beef Skew or whatever it was called was good too with that sauce. The Green Curry and pad Thai was very ordinary. It couldn't beat regular Thai places around here. We took some to-go for late night snacking since we couldn't finished it but we left it at the roulette table!! Dang. 

It was a good new experiment but definitely not a restaurant I would recommend if you're in Vegas. I would say go for lunch or late at night when everything is close. For dinner, go somewhere else. As least their receipt was really thick and nice lol. Don't know if anybody else noticed that.

Beef/chicken satay, rib eye, curries and pretty much anything you order here you will not be disappointed. I've eaten here a few times and always have consistent service with amazing food! Best Thai place in town!

liked it, maybe it was the good company or that i got quite tipsy, but definitely enjoyed the evening. we just walked in and sat at the bar, he had a couple of thai beers and i had a peach ginger cocktail that is now of my favs and will be added to my default drink list. we had the pad see ew (spice level of 10) and a pork and basil rice dish (spice level of 8). and they weren't kidding when they said it would be spicy, then again, i'm not know to handle my spice well, tho i can to a certain degree. the food was good, cooked well, nothing was over done from what i can recall. tho this may not be the best thai i've ever had, but not bad for a hotel restaurant. the drinks were good, the service was good. overall, a good experience =).

As a newbie to Thai cuisine, I cannot compare this to any other Thai places. This particular restaurant had an interesting interior design and was very spacious with high ceilings and ropes that suspended the lighting up in the air and cut across the restaurant. The food we ordered was a spicy soup, green curry, and a noodle dish that was chewy and flavorful. The spicy soup though was my favorite since I love spicy foods, lemongrass, and veggies. The green curry had the right amount of spice and tender chicken. The only thing I didn't like about it was the higher price but hey it's Vegas in a nice hotel/casino so what do you expect right?

This restaurant is perfect for a top notch casual dinner. The atmosphere is great, the dishes are authentic Thai, most drinks we got were made on the stronger side. A meal for four people with two rounds of drinks was less than 100$. My new favorite Thai restaurant on the Strip!

Nice ambience.  Ordered the fried chicken appitizer...it was delish.  It's a little on the pricier side, which is understandable as it is located inside the Aria.

The boyfriend ordered the seafood noodle soup...delish.  Daddy ordered the shrimp wonton noodle soup...delish.  I ordered the yellow curry with beef (special request for the beef, since the menu only says chicken).  They asked how spicy I wanted it, from 1-10.  I ordered an 8...which had a great kick to it!  It was yummy & full of flavor.  

Only disappointment was on the menu, they give a few different options for rice.  Sticky rice wasn't an option, but I asked anyway...and they had it!  Still a disappointment...sticky rice is supposed to be eaten with your hands...and it wasn't manageable with my fingers...had to use a spoon.

Btw...they close @ 2am.  Ordered a pho to go at 1:30am after a long night of gambling.  YUM.  Lots of meat!

This is a great eatery with quality atmosphere and cuisine. It is tucked in the back off of the Casino main floor so it is not easily seen beyond the giant "yellow" wall. Great for people watching even if you are tearing up from the spicy Drunken Noodles. Have been here a few times and love the fact that it is open late and takes Open Table reservations. Families are welcome to sit along side the hot night clubbers. This is a must stop.

Excellent for large groups, we were a group of 22. Everything we ordered was superb and we sampled a lot of the menu given the size of our group. The best was the soft shell crab salad. Reasonable prices for the Strip. They forgot my wife's wine order for a while but the place was packed that night and the excellent food made up for any service shortcomings.

I enjoyed my dinner at Lemongrass and I recommend it if you like Thai food. While I've enjoyed a couple Thai restaurants in Pittsburgh, this place was very good. Oh, and the Pad Thai is served on a spicy scale from 1-10 however 2 is claimed to be average. I got a 4. I like spicy foods, but man a 4 was HOT!! Very tasty though!

Food-
Tom yum soup is good - spicy and sour just the way I like it
Red curry pretty good too
Pork neck meat is delicious, tender and juicy

Service- we ordered takeout so don't know about the service there, but they will call to your room and tell you how long it will take,which is pretty nice 

Overall, surprised Law Vegas has such a nice Thai food restaurant , definitely would recommend to everyone
Excellent Thai food and fair prices! I highly recommend Lemongrass for dinner - I got the Pad Thai and it was amazing!  One of the best meals I have ever had in Vegas.

Overpriced, but then again what is not overpriced on the Las Vegas Strip. I would recommend their Panang Duck Curry. It is very tasteful and has lychee included. It is by far my favorite curry.
