The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is because we asked for the booth we saw...  the host (not manager) said no, however, we notice that when we left after our meal, the whole time we were there the booth was still left vacant.... but fair enough, the booth sat 4 or more and we were just two....  It makes sense.

But I totally support this one.  Really friendly staff who gave great and honest recommendations =)  Delicious!  And quite frankly a shocking surprise of quality on the Vegas strip!

Waited about 15-20 minutes along with a few other parties in front of the hostess desk for the hostess to show up and seat us or at the very least take our names down but to our surprise, no one showed up nor acknowledged our presence.  There were tons of staff walking around and there was even a manager looking person towards the back who failed to even make his way to the front or find someone to assist the ever building crowd.  Never ever have I experienced anything like this.  If the restaurant was busy and packed, I would understand.  However, the place had multiple empty tables.

If this level of service is any representation of the restaurant, I can't even imagine how atrocious the food must taste.

This place was mediocre. My favorite part was the tea . We got pad Thai , spring rolls, basil fried rice , panang curry and pho . Everything was just alright. The spring rolls were mushy in the middle . I've had a lot better for a lot cheaper. High prices for small plates . Atmosphere is very nice though.

Ambiance is nice and staff are very polite. However the food wasn't great. I had shrimp basil with undercooked cold shrimp. The noodles were very dry. The Sticky Rice was almost like me cutting through a brick lol. Maybe it was just a bad night for me

Don't go there! It's expensive AND not good. I took the chicken cashew. No taste and the chicken was so tender that you can be sûre it's not natural. All of my meal was shiny. Yes shiny! Why? It's so discusting! 18$ for something that you can have for 4$ in all others big City? No thank you...

Would rate 3.5.  I've eaten here several times this year during work related conferences.  The staff is fantastic.  Food is very good, and offers a good variety of other Asian cuisines, not purely Thai.  I've had 5 of their soups and they were all great.  Like all of the hotel restaurants in LV, everything is overpriced.  Would be at least 20% less, even in a major metro like SF, LA, NY.

Surprisingly good Thai food on the strip. Like all of the Vegas restaurants, the interior is a sight to behold built with all sorts of rope, wood, as if the modern inteirior was built from found objects in a shipbuilding factory, which is of course impossible in the desert. Anywho, like all vegas restaurants, it is hidden in the back of the Casino but staff here was helping in tracking down the actual location.

We got the yellow curry, the portion size was good to satisfy 2 with normal appetites. The cucumber salad was probably not worth the price but it was tasty and a nice way to start the meal. Everything is very a la carte, and like most of Vegas, rather expensive. Thank goodness for company-sponsored travel :).

Service is attentive and you can bill to your room at any of the "M life" resorts.

The food here was great and it was easy to make a reservation, even on a weekend that was really busy in Vegas.  We ordered 6 dishes family style and it fed 6 girls with good appetites and left enough for a meal's worth of leftovers.  I highly recommend the drunken noodles and the yellow curry.

I just finished eating here with my fiancé.  The best Thai food I have had yet & trust me I have had a lot having lived in NYC, Chicago & SF.  Delicious soup, lobster and fried rice.  Nice staff, our waiter Van was great & kind.  I was told the chef is a executive chef from Thailand and was windowing tonight, but the food is amazing.

Very bland but I think they do this to accommodate every pallet on the planet. (Had the same experience at Noodle no 9 at Caesars). Had beef pad se ewe and it was blank. Had to pile on soy sauce and sriracha to get any flavor out of my meal. Ordered Chicken satay as an app and my gf had cashew chicken. The chicken satay was good. Crisp but tender and served on a skewer adored to a pineapple hunk. Peanut sauce was as expected and the cucumber relish was a little different tasting. Lighter and not nearly as bitter. The cashew chicken was fail

My favorite dish is the cashew chicken with a side of white rice. So flavorful and filling. A bit expensive but delivers a reasonable portion size. Ingredients: chicken, mushrooms, baby carrots, onions and cashews in a delicious light broth.

not bad not great.  

avoid their dimsum menu. very amateurish and probably their worst offerings.

curries are fair. but too sweet and with undercooked veggies. 

their soup noodles are pretty good.

the meats used in their fried noodles and rice dishes are not terribly fresh. you can taste the freezer burn.

I eat a lot of Chinese and Thai food so I know what quality Chinese and Thai food should taste like and this place has it all. They not only serve typical Thai food but they also serve some typical Chinese food as well. The waiters also speak Chinese (Canto and Mando) so if you can't speak English then they can understand your orders in Chinese. I would recommend the Beef Pho, having it here is amazing and one of the best that I've ever had. The only negative I would have for this place is the price. Like all casino restaurants it can be quite expensive for usual simple dishes. But I guess the price comes with quality. And compared to some of the fancier restaurants on the strip this one cost isn't too bad.

It pains me to have to write a review like this. A customer dining in a restaurant inside a world-class hotel and casino like ARIA should not have anything less than an amazing experience. 

It began when I called the restaurant reservation number to make a reservation. I had an important dinner meeting, and I wanted my guest to have an awesome experience. I made a reservation and got a confirmation number. When I arrived at the restaurant,  nobody could find my reservation. I called the reservation line, and after talking to a representative, she encouraged me to talk to the manager. So I requested a manager, but after waiting more than 10 minutes on hold, nobody came back on the line and I hung up. Thankfully, the restaurant was not busy, so they were able to seat us.

When we sat down, I chose a bottle of wine and ordered it. I asked my guest to have the first taste. He tried to be enthusiastic. Then I realized that the bottle we received was a different year than what was on the menu. No wonder my guest struggled. I brought this up to the server, and she didn't think it was a big deal. I requested another bottle.

The meal was good. My desire is that the restaurant will make the experience better for its customers. Not plan on returning here unless things change.

Don't be drawn away from this restaurant simply because of the 3 stars, please. The food is very good! I had the lemongrass chicken, the mint basil chicken, the spicy egplant chicken, and the chicken w/ peanut sauce (yes, shared). While the food was good, it was overpriced for Thai cuisine. Considering the hotel it's in, and the town, the price is rediculously cheap. Now, considering it is thai food, the ambiance and presentation were much better than most quality thai restaurants.

If you want a repleneshing meal that is actually good for you while in vegas, scope this place out!

When you pay extra to go to a nice restaurant, you should get a better atmosphere, better food and better service, so one out of three rates 2 stars.  

The restaurant decorations were very nice.  

The service started out stellar but somewhere in the middle dropped off to the point where our water glasses were empty for a very long time and were finally refilled with warm water.  Our waiter was very nice but took forever to get us the check and we finally had to ask for it.

I ordered the Szechuan beef noodle soup and although it had a great flavor the noodles were mush.  In retrospect I should have sent it back.

This place was absolutely superb all-around.  The ambiance was great, the service top-notch, and the food was best of all!  

I ordered what amounted to some bone-in chunks of chicken served in a large hot pot in a spicy thai sauce with fresh basil leaves mixed in.  The restaurant lets you pick the heat level, and as I like my food spicy, I selected a heat level of 8 (out of a choice of 1-10)  -- the food served matched my personal heat taste perfectly.  

I found the prices moderately high for Thai food, but not for Vegas, nor for the service and swanky ambiance offered.  As far as portions go, the item I ordered came with *plenty* of food presented nicely, and I could not posibly have eaten any more... a *very* large portion in my book that probably could have fed two.  Service was absolutely top-notch.  The server always was on top of drink refills and knew the menu extremely well (warning me as I placed my order that my choice had bones still in the chunks of chicken, for example).  He even gave excellent advice on cocktail pairings with some liqours I have never heard of (that were great, by the way).  I am a hard customer to please, but I don't have a bad thing to say about the place and that is the highest compliment I can give.  Lemongrass may be the only Thai restaurant on the Strip, but when you have one *this* good, who needs another one?

I am giving this a 4 stars because the service was great.  The food is good and the ambience is nice.   Just call ahead or place a reservation on Yelp before going. 

I was nervous about the reviews but this is a good spot.  They can also make almost any dish vegetarian.  Portions are good size too. 

They have a spicy/hot level 1-10.  A 3 is good range and a 4 gets kind of hot (I like spicy for 4 was good for me). It is not that pricey either.  

The dessert was very good! I had the sticky rice with coconut ice cream.  We actually came back for the dessert a day later. 

Over all nice date spot.

Lemongrass has beautiful decor and is nicely situated amidst the Aria Hotel directly near the Sky Suites entrance. The restaurant is actually tastefully done with a central bar and plenty of tables. The food itself is nothing short of average, it isn't terrible but it is by no means terrific. The Satay is essentially the best thing on the menu and you have your choice of meat, I've had the lobster and the beef, both were pretty good. The Phad See Ew with pork wasn't anything to write home about and the overall portion/presentation is simply just average as well. I will say that the Thai ice tea is pretty tasty... The servers were stretched a bit too thin which ultimately resulted in subpar service. Overall, this place is nothing spectacular but if you're wanting late night Thai and want to stay in the vicinity of Cosmo and Aria, then give it a shot. 

Pros-
Nice ambiance 
Location
Decor 
Thai ice tea 
Satay 

Cons-
Food was average 
Service was meh 
Portions a bit small 
Pricey for what you get

We were in Vegas over a month ago and we've been talking about this place ever since. It was late and we wanted to check out Old Vegas so we stumbled upon this place as we were exiting our hotel. It was fairly quiet, but then again it was really late. We started with prawn satay and coconut water. The appy was delicious but not enough to split amongst 2 people, we were left wanting more. We decided to order dinner instead. We had the garlic and lime steamed cod, I remember it being good but nothing memorably. The phad see ew which was kind of like a stir fry with flat noodles, is what we miss the most. I've gone to a few Thai restaurants in Vancouver but none of them do flat noodles like the ones I've had in Vegas!

we came to aria from palazzo cuz our friends wanted to eat at aria buffet and then got sidetracked at sportsbook and didn't want to leave. so my bf and i came here for lunch. we had the thai basil soup, red curry with shrimp, papaya salad, calamari and shrimp salad, har gow and siu mai. everything was delicious. it was $90 for the two of us including tax and tip. kind of pricey for thai food but it's at the aria so what do you expect? the service was impeccable as well.
Shockingly bad. The food was a tasteless sloppy mess. Soggy mush. Considering the hotel/casino, I had pretty high hopes. This food was indescribably bad. They ought to be ashamed of themselves.

Lemongrass was a perfect date night venue for our Valentines dinner in Vegas.  The ambiance was amazing with a very romantic type of venue that made it special than Thai restaurant I have ever been too.  The seafood entrees were terrific and the spice level was to our satisfaction.

I honestly love this place. The staff is great and so is the food. I come here often and every time I make a reservation the service never fails. I definitely recommend eating here. For the price of everything you get huge plates.

Came here after partying at the Bank, needed some recovery food. Located in Aria and it was the closest Pho place I could find. Since its in  Aria you know everything is clean and aesthetically nice, service good, food good, but pricey. 3.5 Stahz!

In a sea of overpriced, greasy, carb laden, sugary food, how nice to have a Tom kha coconut soup and yellow curry. Soup, papaya salad (too much fish sauce), and chicken curry with (yes) brown rice was $44. For a Thai place anywhere else, that's pricy. For Vegas, what a deal.

A group of us dined here for a business gathering and the food and service were wonderful. I ordered the red seafood curry and it was spectacular!  So much so that I've tried several times to re-create it once I returned home :)). The appetizers were fabulous also!  We will be returning next year!

Three others and myself arrived at around 9 pm. We were seated with no reservation after 5 minutes. Ambience is pretty, it was nice and dimly lit. We waited over 10 minutes for our server, Cheng, to come to our table. While he was pleasant, he seemed a little shy and disappeared for most of our meal. The menu wasn't explained to us, nor did he help at all in making suggestions. He was only there to take our drink and food order and drop off dessert at the end. Also, we could barely hear his quiet voice. I appreciated all of the other bussers refilling our water glasses and picking up our finished plates, however.

The food was delicious! The grilled pork neck was the highlight of our meal. Very tender and flavorful. Also, the iceberg dessert was very unique. I loved the corn and rose water flavor, it was delicious. 

I don't think I would come back. Service is part of a dining experience, and tonight's service left me feeling frustrated. But two stars for ambience and food.

I went here tonight with my friend and was totally expecting fabulous food. We were both beyond disappointed and will not come back to this location again. Way over priced for the quality of food with lack of any flavor.

1. Pot Stickers $10
Pan-fried pork dumplings, vegetables, chili-vinegar soy sauce

We ordered the pot stickers and that was the only part of the meal that was good. But then again potstickers are hard to mess up.

2. Then we ordered Pla Lobster** $24
Spicy grilled lobster, fresh herbs, lemongrass, Chinese celery

This consisted of rubbery overcooked Langostinos which are not Lobsters. They were very small, tasteless and chewy. No heat whatsoever or flavor in this salad and it consisted of 98% celery. It should not be called a salad. Nothing salad about it. Someone should explain Salad to these people. 

3. Then we ate the: Garlic and Lime Steamed Cod** $26
Steamed codfish, chili, mint, garlic, lime sauce

So we SAW Garlic on the plate and SAW sliced limes on top of the fish but in no way was this flavor in, around or in any way infused into the fish. My friend could not eat her piece and left it on her plate. I ate mine but had to put chili paste on top to give it flavor. It was even missing salt. In fact the salad and the main entree did not have adequate seasoning, flavor or at the very least salt.

I ordered a Spiced Rum drink with literally NO RUM in it. for $15.00 I would expect some rum in the drink but all I tasted was thai tea and coconut milk.

So $90 later we left hungry and pissed.

I think the only reason this place gets any business is due to their location because their food is horrid and their drinks are light.

Their slogan at the top of the page: "The only authentic Thai restaurant on The Strip" makes me cringe. As a local they have some serious nerve to claim such nonsense. They seriously must appeal to people without tastebuds. If you're a true foodie, run like hell.

A nearby slot machine must have felt bad for me because I won enough in 5 min to pay for my bad dinner. lol

Tucked away somewhere complicated to get to in the Aria hotel is lemongrass, a Thai inspired restaurant. The wait was an hour for a busy Sunday night. The food portion sizes are big so I recommend doing a family style and ordering food to share! The food was okay, just basic overpriced pad Thai. The only thing extraordinary about this place was the peanut sauce that comes with the skewers. It was delicious I loved it and so did everyone I was with! The service is okay, not too attentive and a little aloof but they were busy so it was understandable. The chairs and tables are very awkward the table is low and the booth chairs have low backs so it's an awkward sitting situation. The spicy levels are no joke here so if you aren't a fan of spicy I recommend asking for a 1 or 2 because the 3 was very spicy!

Plush asian restaurant set in the Aria Casino arena with some seriously delicious food.
The ambience is very casual and the super dim lit setting,combined with soft music on the background, makes the whole dining experience very relaxing.You would find a lady going  around the restaurant with a cart of piping hot and amazing dim sums,do try them!

We were here for lunch and ordered a red curry and tom kha soup with tofu. And here comes the important part,when placing your order the waiter would check your desired spice level,  from a scale of 1-10.Be very careful with the number you pick.we picked 7 and boy they are serious about their spicy scale!! We usually consider ourselves very decent with our spice tolerance and they managed to bum us!!! So go with 3-4 if you want a very decent ,no running nose, burning tongue  dining experience.
Having said that, the food is very flavorful and delicious. The soup is amazing with flavor bursting with each sip. Their portion sizes are big.
I only wish I went with a 4 or 5 spice level.

Before you decide to eat here; consider the prices and know that you are on the strip so of course this restaurant would charge you a grip load of money!! Haha why the hell not right? So they say....You're in Vegas $$$! So if you have a budget.. skip this restaurant and spend at the casino. The prices here are ridiculous for mediocre Thai food, it's almost really funny! We were all craving Asian food and didn't want to go far from our hotel and this restaurant came up in our Yelp search and of course P.F. Chang's :/ sad to say.. we should of went to P.F. Chang's...

Nice Huge romantic restaurant inside the Aria Hotel and casino. We were celebrating a bachelorette that night and bought a bottle of moscato ($45) that was soooo good!! sad to say.. that was the only good thing about this restaurant. The food was disappointing. 

1. Beef Pho $18- 2/5 don't be surprised that it didn't taste authentic.. you are at a Thai restaurant tien :( oh why did you have to order this, you Pho addict!!! 
2. Shrimp pad thai 3/5 
3. drunken chicken noodles. 2/5
4. shrimp fried rice. 2/5
5. Duck Curry 2/5
6. $45 bottle of moscato- 5/5 delicious!! one of the best tasting moscatosssss ever!!! Hahah

Service was good, funny dude! However, I wished he would have checked up on us a little more mainly for water!!

Why are we all being considerate about pricing in our review? What ? Money grow on tree for you? 

Pad sea eew = $16
Wonton Noodle Soup = $12
Haw Gaow dim sum= $5.50
Seew Mai dim sum= $5.50
Tea =$5.50/person

We came here for lunch after last night of debauchery LOL. The server greeted us. Here in LA tea is free but not in Aria. These tea are grabbed from snow-capped mountain in ChingChongPoo, China. Tea pickers have to climb 15,000 feet with nothing but ropes to pick these tea leaves. This is the story they like you to believe to justified for the tea pricing. It's rare and taste divine! So they tell me. 

The server said," We have these special jasmine tea for $25!" And at the same time and at the same motion my friend and I pulled back and said "EASYYYY!!!" It was pretty funny when we realized we said it at the same time and pulled our head at the same time.

 We looked at each other and laugh! What's in a tea? Tea leaves and water! Go fuck yourself with the scam! Sorry I don't know what got into me today. It's weekday and work carries over hahhahaha Oh I know I've been watching Gordon Ramsey "F" word show and he cusses alot sorry Love. You should see how he bitch slaps his "Commie" (staff). Funny stuff. Yeap I was at the wrong end of that bitch slap before and it made me a stronger person. What can I say sometimes it's good to take it in the chin. It toughen oneself.

Food was ok, but it's pad see eew how hard is that?
Nice dining area.
Friendly waitress
Ridiculous price for pan fried noodles

$60 total for two people, getting gang bang by Aria priceless.

Definitely not impressed. 
we ordered pad see ew and drunken noodles with seafood. Practically the same looking dishes that arrived at our table. 
There was a good amount of seafood in our dishes but as far as flavor goes it falls FLAT! 
Oh but the Prawn Rolls WERE good. 
We also got a to go curry order, spicy #5 on a scale from 1-10 with 3 being their Medium. The word is 5 wasn't even spicy. At all.
Yum yum everything is good. Expensive Thai but it's Vegas so what do you expect. But the best thing is the superb and attentive service!!!

I liked the ambiance. Very pretty and classy but food was mediocre. Tom yum soup has chewy shrimps N lacked the authentic flavor. Chicken basil was also chewy and was mediocre n lacked basil flavor. Brown rice were good. Go there for a nice dining ambiance but don't expect a good quality Thai authentic experience.

Nice ambiance with a modern feel (very suitable with Aria). We order the crab omelet, pad thai, and shrimp for two. Very yummy. The portion were big enough for a leftovers the next day. 

Pros: not too pricey (considering it's on the strip), good variety of food, great service, little to wait time, open till 2AM, clean, nice bathrooms, and good location in Aria.

Cons: food is not the greatest as the pad thai and shrimp was greasy. Plus drinks are very overpriced.

Overall, a good place to go too if you're on a budget and craving Thai food. Just skip ordering cocktails.

I love the zen atmosphere at this place. The service was nice and it was quick. The prices were average for the strip but that's just how it is. Highly recommend the softshell crab fried rice and the garlic prawns. Superb!

My friend had a gift certificate to Lemongrass so we decided to have ourselves a Thai feast. 

The service here is phenomenal. The server was friendly and quick to take our order and all of our food came out in a sequenced order and in a timely manner. We ordered a seaweed salad and spicy Asian cucumber salad which came out first. Cold and refreshing they were - I absolutely loved the cucumber salad. It had a vinegary dressing and spice to give it a little kick.

Next came out our chicken skewers from the Satay grill which we nibbled on for our appetizer. It came with a peanut dipping sauce that was tangy and delicious! 

For our main course we ordered several dishes. Pad Thai (noodles), Pad Pak (veggies), and a few other unfamiliar chicken/veggie dishes. The food came out hot and tasty! The flavors were mild in the majority of the dishes but still very good.

I still prefer the authentic Thai food you'd find in a mom and pop hole in the wall Thai restaurant. Lemongrass is a popular Thai restaurant on the strip that I would definitely recommend to tourists who want to dine at a hotel/casino.

Looked for some YUM... Got Meh. Service = meh. Oh well....
Lobster Tom Kha - salty! But there were nice big chucks of lobster. 3.5/5
Green curry with Chicken - pass. 2/5
Crab omelette - our server raved about it. We barely touched it. Meh. 2/5

The only reason I didn't give this place 1 star is because they had good service. Food here is not worth the money. The noodles they use are disgusting. My chicken was bland and had a fish texture. The pork they used are all fatty parts. The curry is watered down. And seriously, salmon in egg rolls? What!?

The price is outrageous and the taste does not justify the price, at all. It is hands down the worst Thai food I had in years.

I would compare the food to someone who is not ethnically Thai and tried to make Thai food for the very first time with very little to no instructions.
Amazing food.. The curries red / green and the home style tofu.. Are great value for money!

I agree with the person who would rate this restaurant 3.5.  The food is comparable to many Thai restaurants in Northern California but nearly twice the price for everything.  I tried the seafood chow fun which is Chinese, not Thai, and it was very tasty although a bit on the oily side. There were scallops, calamari and shrimp which were huge, but had a very funny aftertaste like they had been soaked in something.  That aftertaste turned me off so much I had to stop eating them.  The yellow curry with chicken, potatoes, onions and peppers had a nice kick.  We asked for medium heat and It was actually making us sweat. Nice that they didn't dumb it down for the Caucasians.  The pineapple rice was nice too, with huge shrimp.  There were a lot of raisins or maybe currents in nearly every bite which I didn't expect.  The pineapple tasted fresh and the dish was very good with bits of BBQ pork added in for flavor.  Rice was not included so an additional bowl of Jasmine rice for the curry was $3 - 4, which makes me upset..  Any curry that costs nearly $20 or more should include rice.  Shame on them.  The Thai Iced Tea was really good and freshly brewed (as opposed to package mix).  Not a bad meal despite the nickel and dime pricing and the odd non-Thai dishes all over their menu.  The service was very nice and the restaurant was a very creative design of thread, rope and other material that play with the light.  It was dark but sophisticated and I liked the way it was laid out.  If you're in the mood for Thai, or Asian in general, this isn't a bad option but perhaps not my favorite Asian food on the strip.

I went here with a bunch of girlfriends for lunch and would have to say I'm not sure I would come back with all the other available restaurants in the area. The service was really good as they refreshed out plates after the appetizers and kept our water glasses full. We ordered the jellyfish which I thought was good and had a slight kick. The Pad Thai was decent and the yellow curry had alot of onions. I did enjoy the crab omelette and drunken noodles though. I also LOVED the watermelon vodka drink. It was SO incredibly refreshing and I would come back here just to get that!!!

Super glad we picked Lemongrass as one of our restaurants to try on our trip to Las Vegas. Service was very prompt from the start. We both really enjoyed our dishes. My husband had the garlic prawns and I had the mee goreng noodles.  I also had the green tea & gin mixed drink, which was divine. We finished our meal off with the sticky rice with mango. The decor was very unique and elegant - it really set the mood for the meal.

Food was great. I recommend the chicken satay with peanut sauce appetizer. 

I had their watermelon and cucumber drink. It was refreshing and not too sweet.

The food was good and they had a great selection. Service was incredibly slow, however. I think they were understaffed but I never saw Manager and the severs didn't seem to have the hustle. Loved the atmosphere and would eat here again as long as I don't have anywhere else to be and I don't arrive hungry as food will not get to the table anytime soon.

Really Really good food! And the location and ambiance is also great. My husband and I had the Pad See Ew noodles and green curry and it tasted great and the spices were perfect. They were also pretty bug portions. I will definitely come back.

3.5-4 stars overall. Came late night. It's a nice place in Aria. A lot if restaurants closed before 12AM, this was one that was open late and still served a full menu after hours so we decided to try it. 

FOOD:
Chow Mein (3.5 stars): Regular noodles, good, but nothing special. 

Prawn satay (5 stars): Cooked perfectly! I'd recommend this if you like prawns. 

Yellow curry (4 stars): Needs more chicken. Broth was still good though. 

Sake: They only have it warm here, wasn't used to that. I like cold better. 

SERVICE (4 stars):
Everyone was nice but the waiter would disappear at times.

ATMOSPHERE (5 stars):
Nice decor, spacious, clean.
good wontons and nice heavy pour on the drinks.  I'll be back for more.

Food was great and it was located with in casino aria
The coconut water is damm expensive.

First time visit to Lemongrass, menu looked good with moderately priced for what they are offering. Ordered tom kha soup. Food arrived after some wait, smelled good but basically so much lemongrass and chicken gristle it was inedible. Told waitress please take it away with a plate full of lemongrass mulch I had on the plate in front of me. No, I'm sorry you didn't enjoy it, would you like to see a menu for something else. Brought our bill with the "mulch soup" still on it. So many other options in Vegas choose something else.

Great food and not too bad of price. We had a group of 8 and had excellent service. Never had to wait for drinks or had to try to flag down the waitress. I ordered the Yellow Curry and loved it.

The reason I didnt score it higher was because we were sat in the front of the restaurant, so EVERYONE walked by you to their table

First off we luv this place!

Been coming here whenever Vegas for a few years and it never fails to delivery.

From the freshest coconut water (I'm Caribbean so I know the difference and this is legit), to my fav the salmon spring rolls its always a delight. I'm also addicted to the pineapple rice and the '3 cup chicken'!

On those who are complaining, I honestly can't say what I find wrong and this is literally my nth time in last few years. Everyone I bring here luvs it.

Take out is also awesome.. we do this with my family quite a bit. 

I recommend it for when you want some privacy, good service, a bit of class.
I'll be back in 4 weeks!

Service at the bar was borderline rude.  Prawn appetizer was greasy.  

I told the bartender that I was going to the bathroom and that is be right back.  When I got back, my food had been thrown away.

The decor included a drunken girl slouching asleep at the bar next to me.

Not what I expected.

Not impressed.

Decent Thai food, but nothing out of the ordinary to justify the $18/dish price point.  Ambiance and decor were nice, as expected for being located in the beautiful Aria hotel, however the restaurant itself was quite loud which made conversation difficult.

Spice level was on point, the lack of which is such an annoyance to me at most Thai restaurants.  I think they really followed the Thai Hot scale on this one.  The spice level masked the lack of flavor in most of the dishes.

We took home leftovers but never ate them.  I think that says something in itself...

As my sister put it (without words), "it's life changing" hahaha

Loved it and would happily go again.

This place is not exactly a wow, but not a horrible choice. Pretty trendy feel to it, good background music. 

However the service is below average. 

The food quality is average. Nothing special.
Very poor service, took forever to get our food and our bill. Overpriced for mediocre Thai but it's Vegas so to be expected

One of the best thai restaurants I know. But today's experience was brutal. 1 hour wait time. I brought my brother who is visiting from europe. I asked manager if she could let us seat sooner than 1 hour considering as I was Mlife platinum member and visiting lemongrass every week. I probably have spent total $5000+ at lemongrass before for so many visits. Manager seemed rude and did not care if I was VIP customer or not. Very disappointed. You guys need new manager who cares more about vip customers coming every week. I will make sure to spread my disappointment everywhere I can.
REALLY good Thai... beautiful décor, great service, would definitely go again!

This restaurant has a beautiful ambience. It has a very romantic candle light setting and it's located in the Aria which is beautiful as well, also it's fairly reasonably priced. I recommend the yellow curry chicken with a side of white rice.

What a joke. We had an awesome waitress... up till we ordered our meal. She informed us that her shift was ending, so we got stuck with Alex, and over the next five times someone came to the table, we had a different person each time.

My drink ran out three times.

No freakin' way. One time is barely tolerable. But three times? 

The place was not overwhelmingly busy. There were at least nine tables around me that were empty, and only four of them occupied. Not sure what the problem was.

The food was *decent*... the fried rice seemed to have a bit too much oil. My friend's Mongolian Beef was overwhelmed with onions... it seemed as if there were more onions than meat.

Overall, the ambiance (Edison-style lights are awesome) was unbelievably gorgeous... but that's about where the Pros list ends and the Cons start. 

Better luck next time... but there are so many places in LV/on the Strip that this won't be worth a return visit anytime soon.

overall- OK, not the best Thai restaurant ever. I have tasted much better. Also, the portions are very, very small. I would recommend this for couples. On the expensive side.

By the way, I would definitely recommend reservations if you are reading this. The concierge at Aria said they didn't take reservations...but they did, and we had to wait 45 mins. :(

The service was not very good first of all. My family tried to get a few bowls so we could share the dishes, but they didn't give it to us until we asked a million different waiters ( exaggerating, of course). We were wondering why the waiters were standing around chilling when we asked for bowls...?!

Anyways, we ordered Tom Yum Goong, and Tom Yum Tay ( or something like that) and they basically tasted the same. Tom Yum Goong was a little bit sweeter though. You can choose what spiciness level you want. 

We also ordered soft shell crab fried rice, satay chicken, and creamy red curry with prawns (I forget the name in Thai).

Fried rice - I thought it was good, just a bit bland. My family thought it was nothing special. Comes with fried crab pieces on the side.

Satay chicken - the chicken was good, but the peanut sauce wasn't. The bread was good though.

Curry - I thought this was probably the best part of the meal. Delicious. Creamy. It was small, and came with only a  few (maybe a bit more) prawns.

The restaurant was very high class ( in Aria ) and a bit formal dress is probably good ( not necessary, though )

Hope you enjoy this review and it was helpful!! Also, thank you to the first reviewer for helping my family and I decide what to order.

Service is ridiculously slow especially when it's 11am and there's only 4-5 tables present. It took them about 10 min to sit us because the host wasn't even at her post. Food was mediocre at best you'd be better going off strip but if you don't have a car then this is your best bet in aria for asian food.

I wouldn't recommend this place unless you had transportation or hight want to eat Asian food else where.

Lemongrass is located inside Aria hotel right next to blossom. I came here for lunch two days ago with a party of about 10. The service was awful. When we sat down, there was no waiter to be found anywhere near by. I kept having to turn my head back and forth just so I can wave one down. I had to walk to the hostess stand to ask for some menu's to look at. By the time the waiter came, we were ready to order. 

I ordered the thai tea as my beverage. It took almost 10 minutes to come out. The thai tea wasn't sweet enough. I've had better. 

My boyfriend & I shared the jellyfish and the Lemongrass prawns as the appetizers. I don't recommend the jellyfish. It was too largely cut that it was so hard to chew. I wish it was thinly sliced. So the "Lemongrass prawns" came out. And it looks like a fishcake or something. So I asked the waiter what it was and he said fish cake. I told him we didn't order that and that was ordered prawns. So he added that in as well. Then the "prawns" came out and it was an eggroll prawn. There was 3 different waiters at this table and they were all saying different things. Finally we verified that it was the Lemongrass prawn and just turn into a mousse. The Lemongrass Prawns was actually pretty decent. It was just a hassle to figure out what everything was. 

As our entree we ordered the drunken noodles with seafood. It was okay. The portion was kind of small. There wasn't enough flat noodles. It was about $20 for this dish. 

I thought this restaurant was pretty pricey for an "Asian" restaurant. And it wasn't even satisfying.

I am really impressed with the service, quality, and of course the food! We ordered the jellyfish which is kinda like the texture of tripe and was a little on the sweet and spicy side. We had the vegetable fried rice which was sooo delicious and had a great smokey flavor. The pad Thai was declicious too although a bit spicy for being ordered as mild. And lastly, we ordered the red curry with duck... Wow so good! We. Would definitely come back again not only because of the food but for also the quality of their customer service.
Had a very good experience dining there. The ambience , service and presentation was definitely top notch. Am a great fan of Thai food and this definitely is recommended.

The food was good but not awesome good...

My family came here to eat some Thai food and the decor and plating was very awesome. I ordered Drunken Noodle with Chicken and the noodle was kinda bland. The spicy ness of the food stayed on your tastebuds! I then tried some of the Fried Rice w/ basil and Beef, it was ok not the best. It also didn't have much of a flavor but the beef was very tender!! The Pad Thai on the other hand was phenomenal! The crushed peanuts, the spices, the noodles was all great! The bill was a little over priced but it's Vegas.

Lemongrass is billed as the strip's first Thai restaurant at a major resort casino. The restaurant's location is ideal, tucked away from the main casino located adjacent to the high limit baccarat casino, Club Prive (high end gaming), the Sky Suites lobby, and Blossom (chinese restaurant). The decor of the restaurant is decidedly modern, with warm earth tones and decorative pipes serving as walls. 

I found the food to be (not to my surprise) very americanized with the exception of the duck and yellow curry, which my party decided to order spicy. The menu allows you to pick your spicy-ness on a scale of 1-10. Because of this, I believe that the higher you go on the hot scale, the more Thai the food will taste. The pineapple fried rice and drunken noodle were bland, and were served in extremely small portions. The orange chicken however was probably the best orange chicken I have ever eaten as the chicken meat was still juicy on the inside. 

All in all, I would recommend Lemongrass as a good place to eat Thai food if you care more about overall ambiance than authenticity of the food. Its location next to the Sky Suites lobby makes it convenient if you are staying on that side of Aria. As another added bonus, the restaurant is open for lunch at 11 am and is open late till 2 am so if your craving Thai food to cure your hangover, Lemongrass is the place to go.

Food was good . Nice flavors good temp. The only reason I'm giving it any stars was because of the food. AS FOR THE SERVICE.... one of the worst I've ever experienced. No refils, no asking us if our food was fine, waited 45 mins for our check and couldn't find our server.  We finally noticed him messing and chatting away with the cooks and some other servers.. Meh.

My First Time !! ( Vegetarian )

Greeting : We had to wait for 2 hours. 

Attitude of the people around there serving : Ok.

Beverages : Green Tea was good. 

Main Course : 

Fried Rice : It was served well, delicious and well portioned. 
Yellow Curry : Very delicious. 

Overall : The food was good.

Service : Decent.

Ambience : Very elegant.

Overall : The experience was good. 

Will I go next time : Not sure.
Drunken noodles and pork neck were really tasty and spiced well. I would definitely come back again.
Great food, great atmosphere. The food portion of food and man it toast good. Just keep an eye on how much you eat, it can add up.

Ambience is excellent! I am a vegetarian ND I was really glad to see the options there. Spring rolls were amazinng but was a little dissatisfied with the entree- fried tofu mixed vegetables. Tofu pieces were too big and the gravy wasn't great either. Liked Garlic fried vegetables. Found the Entrees a bit too pricy for the quality.

Lets see. SERVICE was not so bad, but it sure was freakin slow....FOOD was exceptional, I favored the pineapple fried rice and thats about it...I hate that you have to pay  $3 for a bowl of steamed rice, The atmosphere felt good though, the decor helped make it ambient, attractive, and at the same time quiet relaxing, late night open restaurant...thats a thumbs up! Yes, its Vegas, but still some restaurants or eats are hard to find. The pho was well, but other than fried rice and pho, the food was just eh....the prices you know..its Vegas...as the flight attendant said...lost wages.

Was greeted and seated promptly.

Didn't know dim sum was served here, so we were pleasantly surprised to see the dim sum on wheel carts while following the hostess to our table.  (Today is Sunday, so I am not sure if dim sum is available on just Sundays, on both Saturday and Sunday, or every day).

The staff is very attentive and friendly.  The suggestions our waitress recommended were on point.  Well, except for the papaya salad, which lacked the kick that most papaya salads have.  Barely tasted the fish sauce or lime in it.   

Loved the sea bass, the marinated fried squid.  If you're in the Aria and you're craving Asian / Thai'ish (yes, I said "ish") food, Lemongrass is definitely worth checking out.  Pricing is also reasonable.  My party of 3 ate 4 selections of dim sum, sea bass, marinated fried squid, papaya salad, brown rice, and we also drank 2 Thai teas and 1 fresh-cocunut juice for a total of $103 pre-tip.  More importantly, we were FULL AND SATISFIED.  Worth coming back to try out more of what their menu offers.

90$ for 4 people, drinks, entrees, and 1 appetizer. Huge portions too. Talk about DEALIO for vegas standards/prices.

I'd highly recommend this restaurant for foodies on a budget since although Vegas has a tremendous set of fancy, amazing restaurants to offer, it's not within most people's price range (plus, it is extremely hard to book reservations for the places that are to die for like Robuchon!) so run towards the middle and go to Lemongrass. They strangely have dim sum at lunch hours...but besides that, they offer comfort food for $20 or less. Satisfying and delicious. The restaurant is beautiful too. If I stay at the Aria again I would def venture over here again and again!

My best friend just to happened to have planned a Vegas trip the same weekend I was going to be in Vegas, how crazy is that?!  She was staying at the Aria and we decided on going to Lemongrass for dinner.

There was no wait at 7:45/8:00PM on a Saturday night which was great!  I would categorize Lemongrass as an Asian Fusion restaurant.  They make a bunch of different Asian dishes.  The food is good but not great.

We ordered a TON of food:

Fried Prawns
Jellyfish
Spicy Cucumbers
Chicken Wings
Vegetable Fried Rice
Three Cups Chicken
Beef Pho
Pork and Pickled Vegetable Noodle Soup (Xue Cai Rou Shi Mian)
Spicy Beef Noodle Soup (Nu Rou Mian)

The Fried Prawns were YUMMY.  The prawns are huge, and the dipping sauce compliments the flavors so perfectly.

I quite enjoy jellyfish, but this one tasted a little too water-y.  They must've washed the jellyfish and possibly soaked it in tap water, because there was an overwhelming tap water flavor when I bit into the jellyfish.

The Spicy Cucumbers were seasoned with the right mixture of vinegar, sugar and spice.  It actually tasted really similar to the appetizer you'd get from a legit Chinese restaurant.

I got the Beef Pho and was a little underwhelmed.  I felt like I got more beef, tripe, flank, and whatever else they put in my soup than noodles.  And because the beef, tripe, flank etc. looked weird, I had a difficult time wanting to eat it.  I ended up having a big pile of that stuff on my side plate.

The server seemed to be in love with one of the girls and would be SO chipper and smiley with her.  Anything she needed, he'd get for her.  I believe his name is Van.

This was a pleasant dinner, and somewhat affordable.  I think I'd rather try some of the other restaurants at Aria, perhaps the buffet, next time.

I haven't felt this sexy in a long time.

A group of seven of us dressed to the nines and showed up at Lemongrass.

First off, the Aria on its own is a beautiful casino and a great alternative on the North Side of the strip as opposed to the rundown hustle and bustle of Freemont Street hotels.

Secondly, the Lemongrass restaurant was probably the best Thai Food I ever had.  I ordered a level 7, which was at the time I mistake.  But the curry was so good that I kept eating it, mouth burning, and a Sapporo to wash it down, that by the time I realized I was too full to eat anymore, I couldn't stop shoveling it in my mouth!

Yes.  Shoveling.  I'm not the kind of girl you can take to eat in public.  lol.

The server was friendly and he got all of our orders perfectly correct.  The kinds of places I usually eat, one has to worry about that kind of thing often in a big group.

The total bill was something like $250, for the seven of us.  We all ordered an entree and a beverage or two.  Because it was our friend's birthday, she got any drinks she ordered comp'd.  That was nice of the waiter!

I can picture myself eating here again next time Vegas calls my name.  Heck, I could even picture myself staying at the Aria.

Incredible experience at this restaurant. My boyfriend and I shared 3 entrees and they were each outstanding. The spiciness of the food was just right. This is the best Thai food ever had. I stopped eating Thai for a while because none of the restaurants were making the food right, but this place gave me hope on trying new Thai places. The decor is gorgeous and the service was great. I will have to make a stop here whenever I'm in town.

Lemongrass provided good Thai food but at Las Vegas prices. We split the three course fixed price menu ($59) that included several things. We added calamari and two drinks and were completely stuffed. 

The calamari seemed to be battered in funnel cake batter- it was REALLY good. Chicken satay and prawn roll were included in the fixed price, they were good, nothing amazing. Main dishes were basil beef, chicken pad thai and something else... can't remember. The best part of the basil beef was the giant onion ring it was served in, kind of like a bowl.Desert was good as well, but don't remember what it was besides being in warm coconut milk.  

Overall I was left with a ... meh.... impression. Very nice place, food was good, service was good. But seriously, how can you really spruce up Thai food? I get it locally where I live and pay $15 for food for two people with leftovers and its just as good. I wouldn't come here expecting to be impressed, its just plain old good Thai food.

I'm a big fan of Thai food, so after a week in the U.S. I had been craving a good Green Curry. Unfortunately, I didn't find it at Lemongrass.

The service was excellent, so no complaints there. The food was extremely average though, and definitely not worth the price. We ordered satay chicken and Tom Kha Gai for starters, and green and yellow chicken curries for mains (entrees). All of the meals were well presented, but extremely bland in taste. The Tom Kha soup had too much lime juice, and the curries were both almost tasteless aside from the spiciness (we ordered very mild, as we prefer the taste to the spice). The satay chicken was better, but still much too subtle in terms of flavour.

I wouldn't recommend this if you're looking for somewhere to eat in Vegas, but there aren't many options available if you want Thai food. Disappointing.

So many delicious vegetarian options to pick from! Great ambiance and good service. One of my most favorite restaurants in Vegas. You must try the fresh coconut water, its served in the whole fresh coconut and i felt like i was transported to a tropical island. Definitely worth going back here next time I'm in town!

After a night out and skipping dinner, we were starved! We really wanted to try the Mexican restaurant in Aria but they were closing (boo!). After asking which restaurants are still opened we chose Lemongrass. 

The decor is pretty and modern. The booths are hard to get into though! You cant just slide in. On the table they have a cup with wooden/bamboo chopsticks. I personally think if it was an upscale Asian restaurant they'd be pretty and reusable but that's my opinion. 

We ordered Tom Kha Chicken to start which was awesome. They didn't spoon the soup into individual bowls which I thought was odd. I guess I'm just use to Asian restaurants doing that. For our main course we had black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, some kind of curry, and I think Chow Fun. All tasted good but weren't outstanding. I guess I've had better Thai/ Chinese food with better service for cheaper back home. But then again I have to give them credit for being open so late. 

After adding some sodas, beers, and white rice the total was well over $100. Overall I doubt I will return even for late night grub.

Favorite thai Restaurant!! Service was amazing! We ordered Chicken Satay, Shrimp Phad Thai, Chicken Curry, Fish Cake and Yang Chow Fried Rice!! Price was pretty reasonable! Too much food in our table that we had to take home some. 

Thai iced tea btw was for the win :) 

I will definitely recommend lemongrass.

Typical Las Vegas. 
Food mediocre at best.  Not really Thai but more of a mixture of Asian cuisine.  Just an ok option for late night dining. 

Service..... awful. 
First off the hostess seats us at a dirty table with literally sticky sauce she clearly sees and proceeds to let me clean it because moving us to one of the 25 empty tables is too much to ask. Oh but she did offer me an extra napkin since I had to use mine to clean the table.
The restaurant was maybe 1/3 full but the waitstaff was MIA for some time when a young man came to our table and told us our waitress was busy so he can take our order. 
Once he took our order it was quite some time before we got our drinks, just a soda but flat. The next time we saw him we told him the sofa was flat and he offered to get us something else but I asked if they could just replace the co2 but he literally said no. Ok fine. 
Then it took about another 20 minutes to get our appetizers and even longer for our meal. 

The food... eh. Very lacking in flavor and I would not recommend eating chicken since both things we ordered had a very rubbery weird version of chicken. 

I would not recommend this place at all.  We paid about $90 for 2 dishes and 2 appetizers. Waste of money.

Lemongrass At Aria -- EEKS methinks NOT fer sure!

What were we thinking going for Thai in Vegas anyway!? That explains why this place was the only one that we can get a reservation for a big party last minute.

The servers were all friendly... but not very attentive. We asked for water and followed up nicely 3 more times and it didnt come until we were pretty much done with our meal.

The food were nothing special. They were all blah and bland. We had their "best appetizer" prawn roll which looked amazing but it   was nowhere near any prawn or shrimp rolls Ive tried even in the hole in the wall type of places. 

We tried pretty much all their noodle dishes. They were all not satisfying!
Some dish were super spicy like the shredded pork and beancurd, and the menu didnt even say it was a spicy dish. 

How can a Thai restaurant go wrong with Mango sticky rice? ... but they did. It just didnt hit the spot for us.

What an experience. It's a modern twist of Thai cuisine. The Decor is high-class and encompasses the true meaning of high class. The servers are not only knowledgeable about their product, but meticulous about providing impeccable service.

Lets move on to the food. Boy Oh boy is it good. rest assured the price you pay is worth every 1/100th of every cent. It really does leave you wanting more and more.

Protip: despite what you may assume or have experienced at other places they have a spicy scale of 1-10 ....and if you pick 10 (like i did) WATCH OUT it's like a bonfire in your mouth and you will start mysteriously sweating.

Most places are afraid to make things too spicy.....these guys arent and i LOVE THAT!!!!!!!

Overpriced, confusing hodgepodge. Typical Vegas restaurant with no identity. Even waiters were laughing at the selection in the Dim Sum cart. We asked if anything had chicken. The waiter stuck out his tongue and laughed, "Chicken feet!".  The food was ordinary. But the surrounding architecture is something to figure out as you try to figure out why you ate here. Very few real Thai dishes on menu.

So I'm enjoying an afternoon of Vegas poker at the Aria with a few friends. We're throwing chips around, enjoying drinks, as well as our profits. None of us want to leave the table with the oil exec from Houston and the French tourist who likes to bluff. I don't know what it is but I really enjoy taking money off the French. Gonna have to look in to that. Anyway, I'm a little hungry and after my fourth greyhound I need some food. But I wanna keep it healthy and light so I call the brush. She hands me a menu to Lemongrass for table-side service which I will gladly tip her well for. I see brown rice on the menu for $5 and I ask the brush to tell them to add a side order of broccoli. She says no problem and I tip her $5 for ordering/picking it up.

She comes back a few minutes later with the bill and its for $24 and change?????? I'm  confused, and assume she mixed my order up with another but no. I tell her to hold the order and let me know what the $24 charge is for (I'm staying upstairs and assume they'd charge my room cc at some point). She said that the manager said they don't do sides of broccoli and had to order the vegetarian dinner. I again am confused and let her know the vegetarian dinner is full of brown rice, noodles, and a mixture of veggies and mushrooms (is that a vegetable or a fungus?). She said the manager said this is all they can do for me. I tell her to cancel the order and say keep the tip for your efforts.

After my button passes I take a walk across the casino to the restaurant, more like a cafe. The manager is extremely smug and rigid. I am utterly shocked by his lack of customer service to not only a gambling guest, but a hotel guest as well. He makes some snide comment about me not wanting to pay or not "having enough" to pay for my meal. Again, completely shocked I decide to make a statement and accidentally drop my wad of gambling c-notes on his counter which he picks up and hands back to me. Douchey as it was, this pompous cafe manager had to be put in his place.

I returned to the poker table where we shortly left to get some Nobu at Hard Rock.
It was a great trip but this was more surprising than anything. I still love the Aria and their poker room, I'll just steer clear of this place.

This review is based mostly on the service and bua loy dessert. My boyfriend and I went here for restaurant week. We ordered pad thai and chicken curry. We said we wanted the spice mild. Well, the food was not mild. It wasn't that the food wasn't good. It really was, but we couldn't handle the spice. I think I got full off of all the water I drank. The servers were very attentive  and even offered to redo the dish. The bua loy dessert was heavenly though..... It was the best thing ever...... So creamy.... so smooth..... so sweet..... so good.... and it cooled down my mouth from all the spice.....I would come here again but just for dessert.

I am not sure what other reviewers are talking about...This place was not good. That is putting it mildly.

The panang curry was swimming in its own grease and there were huge chunks of bone in the duck that was in the pool of grease.

The pad thai J was flavorless and the tofu was dried up little chunks.

The server was funny and friendly and the kirin was tasty. 

If you are in the area, I would go to one of the many other places that are in the Aria...not here.

I loved it! Service was excellent, food even better!
I got noodles that were out of this world with flavor, never had better to this day. Also tried my friends meal which was some kind of spicy beef that also rocked!
And good god, for dessert I tried the coconut soup, yes for dessert you heard me right haha. I can't say it was like a broth because it was way creamy, it is served warm and is supposed to cleanse your palate before you eat a "real dessert" as my fiance would say (which I'm not gonna lie,I ate most of his fried bananas too). Just typing this makes me want that soup sooooo bad! I can't describe how yummy it is.
Also side note- fried bananas were terrific as well, they use plantain and are the best I have tried so far, great sauce on it and a ton of ice cream is put on the side of it. 
You can even order a coconut with the milk in it to drink out of!
Will be back...
 And soon, cuz now I want that soup!

Soo goood!  They are true Thai and understand the spice levels properly.  We ordered a Basil Beef (level 5) and the traditionally Thai coconut soup.  Soooo goood!   We also had some dim sum which was decent quality and not too bad prices.  I am would go here again!
Great traditional Thai! I highly recommend Lemongrass

The service was good and the food came out fast. Reservation was recommended but it wasn't as busy as some of the other famous strip restaurants. 
Pad Thai I had ordered was a 7/10 spicy which simply equated to more Chili peppers.

Went to this place twice over our weekend stay in Vegas. Once for take out and once for dine-in. We usually stay at MGM, and I'd compare to this restaurant to the Grand Wok in MGM in terms of tiers of restaurants.  Pricing (for Vegas that is) and food were really good! We ordered the yellow curry and pad see ewe one night and green curry and a noodle soup on the next.  The pad see ewe was just okay in the husband's opinion, but the curries and noodle soup dish were pretty tasty.  The spice levels were just how I liked it, and it was HOT, but I kind of wished it was a bit more coconut-flavored.  Nonetheless, the dishes were still great, and they were good meals. Service was great as well.

I thought that the food here was pretty good, and service was excellent, but I wouldn't have come here if this wasn't one of the only places open at the Aria at 11pm.  We ordered the crab fried rice and the chili shrimp.  The crab rice was good, with chunks of crab meat, but the dish was overall a little bland and benefitted from some chili sauce.  The shrimp was cooked perfectly, but it was overall only marginally better from any neighborhood Thai place but at 2x the price.

Yummy Thai food!  The Panang curry was silky and luscious, although we would have liked to been asked our spice preference (we just like our curries hot!).  Definitely a small complaint.  They did the basics like potstickers and pad thai really well.  There aren't a lot of thai places on the strip, and this was a welcome find.

Three stars for an average place.  Great decor and clean. But for being on the strip and especially in the highly talked about city center I expected more. We had a reservation for a small group of us and were seated right away. Service was good but nothing over the top.  Our group did the tasting menu which I enjoyed but wasn't blown away.  The food was flavorful and when they warn you about things being spicy they are right. We didn't feel rushed and enjoyed our evening but I'm not aching to go back.

I would consider this Westernized Thai and would not have selected to eat here but..
1. It was our first night in Vegas
2. It was getting late
3. We were all hungry
4. We needed a place to round up the troops
5. We had to get ready and head out to the club ASAP

eating just before 10pm, the place was still pretty packed and we waited for about 15 minutes before a table for 15 opened up. The waitress who seemed very nice in the beginning eventually became more grumpy throughout the night.

A variety of dishes were ordered to share, family style. Between my few friends who opted for this suggestion, we got a singapore style noodle with peppers, shrimp and the works. It was tasty, good filling and nice fusion-like flavours. To try something different, we got a chicken hot pot, which was cooked beautifully. It had spice and kick to it, while the chicken was saucy and tender. Piping hot, this was my favourite. A staple dish that I use to order when available was pineapple fried rice. Usually at the "hole in the walls," the rice was actually served in a half of a pineapple and little bits can be scraped out at the end. However, this was just served on a plate and the worse pineapple fried rice I've ever tasted - no joke. The rice was dry and burnt. There was lack of flavours and just hard to eat. I tried to consume more of the other dishes to satisfy my hunger instead.

The prices seemed reasonable, with some lobster delicacies as high as $110. Not sure if it would be worth it.

You know, I really wish I could give this place 4 or 5 stars.  BF & I have eaten here several times (mostly when we've stayed, because you don't really want to walk down the strip full) and he always seems to enjoy it more.  I'd personally give this a 3.5, he'd probably rank this a 4.25.

There's just nothing that special about it.  Everything looks really nice.  Everything seems fresh and well prepared.  But off the top of my head, there's nothing that screams, holy cow I have to get you again.  Save for (and this would be my 0.5 increase), the strawberry gelato.  There is nothing like it.  And nothing else in the line really matches its par.  Oh well, that and the spicy pepperoni pizza (I know, of all the things).  They make their own na'an, which is good, but is kind of useless because the dishes they offer for you to eat it with are well, 'blah.'

Service is always great, and pricing isn't too bad.  Actually, you can't really complain about price when stuff is comp'd.  Line is never too long either.

It's not that I don't recommend eating here, it really is just more of, I wish they had a better tasting selection.

I live in Portland, Oregon, a place that boasts a Thai restaurant every block. This place was fantastic...we had the yellow curry (sub tofu for chicken) and the pad see ew. Everything was fantastic. Some of the best Thai food I've had in quite a while.

This place dishes out some of the best Thai I have ever eaten. I'm adventurous, so I began with the prawn rolls and moved on to the Pad Thai Beef. My waiter did warn me several times that it was going to be spicy, but then, he didn't know that I am a true fan of Thai cooking!
  
It's open late, which is nice for night owls. It is Vegas after all. I can always find something interesting here!
Nice place with cool decor, but the service is far away from the best.

I had the yellow curry here and even though it is really hard to mess up this dish, I thought is was pretty good. 

I would not come back here to order this particular dish but it was the least expensive sharing item. I thought this place was a bit pricey, but the city center theme was created to be upscale so it is understandable. 

I also had the papaya salad that came with the coconut rice. It was very good. 

Being a local and having so many great thai food restaurant options, I would never head out to lemongrass just to have lunch. But if the presentation and ambiance is important to you, it would be the way to go.

My friend and I had lunch here and were trying to plan our resolutions for 2010. We were interrupted a bit too much as the waitresses were very eager to please. I don't mine an occasional excuse me, and checking up if the food was OK, but literally interrupted me more than 5 times. I would have preferred that they recognize that we were having a conversation and just refilled my water and took my plates away rather than interrupt me.
I ordered the drunken noodles with shrimp - soo good.  totally hit the spot.  The decor is great and even though its in the casino you cant really hear all the noise.
Very mediocre food and horrible service I will never ever return to this establishment.
I really enjoyed the ambiance of this restaurant. It's secluded away from the gaming floor and really feels like it's on its own property. The Chicken Satay is a must. Can't wait to go back!

We ate here before going to a show in the same hotel.   When we asked the maitre'd what the difference was between the Lemongrass and the one across the way (Blossom), she said "They are fine dining and we're not" so I stayed.  The scallops were delicious but everything was just a bit too spicy for my taste.   The waiter seemed unhelpful when asked for his opinion on different dishes and cocktails.  One of the specialty cocktails ("something Leopard") tasted medicinal.  My biggest recommendation would be the salmon rolls for an appetizer.  They were really good.
The dim sum is so delicious. Love that there open late night the service was good lacking some ambience but overall good staff and food experience.

During my time in Vegas, I visited Lemongrass a number of times. It was always very good. Consistently good and had good service as well and at a reasonable price.

I eat a LOT of thai food and I have to say that Lemongrass has some of the better Thai food I've eaten, not the best, but it's very good. 
I often started with the chicken satay which is standard but good and/or the tom yum soup which had a bit more flavor than a number of other tom yum soups I've had.

For the entree, I've had a number of things. My favorite Thai dishes are yellow curry and panang curry and Lemongrass offers high quality curries, both had good flavor and spice without overwhelming and the consistency of the curry was correct as well, not too runny like some places.
They have plenty of fried rice options which are good and also offer a good pad see ew. One of the times I was there, a friend got the crab which was a full crab on a plate. I'm allergic, but it was very cool to see and looked incredibly fresh and delicious. 

Overall, I always enjoyed Lemongrass and would gladly recommend it to others.

Had a vegetarian Pad Thai J for lunch today. Too oily and need to add lots of soy sauce. I didn't enjoy it that much n the portion is kinda small. Love their soft tofu pudding!  Very fresh n soft :) good service too
I get the beef pho to-go. Not just because of hangovers but bc I actually like it. And it's one of the few spots on the strip that serves it

For what it is, it is ok. A hight priced Thai restaurant in a 5 star hotel. I had the chicken coconut soup and Pad See Ewu... A flat Noodle dish with chicken. It was good but not great. I've had better Thai food elsewhere. Stick with Lotus of Siam or that Thai place downtown.

Service was quick and friendly, not overly intrusive.

When I lived on the strip, I used to eat here regularly! I love the pho but sometimes it is not super hot (which pisses me off)! I also love the watermelon vodka drink. If I eat pho and have two drinks my bill is around $50. It could be a bit pricey. But it's on the strip, what'd ya expect, right?

Skip the steamed Sea bass. A bit too fishy. 

Like the chicken and corn soup. Solid. 

We asked for sautéed bokchoy, asparagus and mushroom and it was pretty good. 

Nice ambience especially for dinner settings.

We usually stay at Vdara because it's clean, quiet and bigger rooms.  We always walk over to have Lemongrass.  I love their Yellow Curry, Seafood Noodle Soup, Prawn Rolls and Potsticker.   I can't wait to try their other stuff.
This place is overpriced, has a limited selection, the service is slow even when empty and they seat everyone on top of each other. Really really terrible. Highly re come d skipping this one.

We wanted pho and asian food.. we didnt want to drive far to get some asian food and they have good reviews so we came here.
 My friends ordered pho and dimsum my bf and i ordered pad see wu and sweet amd sour chicken.. surprisingly pad see wu was good not the sweet and sour chicken. The pho was very diffrent from how we normally eat it. The pho had a strong taste cinnamon.. not use to that. 
Dimsum was really good too. It had a very clean taste not salty or oily.
Last-i love thai tea. Thai tea was very good :)

The best bang for your buck Thai/Asian fusion on the strip!

I love food. Vegas, despite being a culinary hot spot, can be hard to find something right for me. I'm not a buffet person. Fast casual is great, but not for every meal. And the same goes for high end dining- I'll do it for something special, but it'll break the bank if I go every night. Lemongrass hits that rare sweet spot of being somewhere in the middle. It's a sit down restaurant with a nice ambience, provides tasty food in decent portions, all while being reasonably priced.

Speaking of tasty food, Lemongrass carries one of my favorite dishes ever-- the Mee Goreng. Consisting of wok-fried yellow noodle, fried tofu, egg, potatoe, chili, tomato, choy sum and chicken (or your choice of beef or shrimp), it hits all the right notes. The sauce is slightly tangy and sweet while the egg, potato and chicken add a savory flavor. It's served in a hearty portion with the ability to choose your level of spice. When I visit a Thai restaurant for the first time, I always wonder if they are going to white-wash the spice level. This is not the case here with a level 6 nearly burning my palate off (just how I like it!). Last time I visited the waitress even said I'm more Asian than her! If mee goreng isn't your thing (it should be), Lemongrass also offers a variety of other dishes such as rice, curry and even lobster or steak. They have good appetizers too-- I'm a huge fan of the spring rolls (they're fried so don't come here right before the pool) and one of my friends swears by the jellyfish.

Usually there isn't too bad of a wait and you can make reservations in advance. The staff have always been prompt and friendly. I can't say enough good things about this place. It's always a must when I come to Vegas!

The food was decent but very greasy and the portions were too large.  Maybe it was just what I ordered (vegetable egg rolls and home cooked tofu in a hot pot), but the other three guests at my table had similar sentiments.  The ambiance is great and the service was good.
Tom kha chicken soup, chicken cashew, young cho fried rice. Everything was amazing and full of flavor!
Edible. Nothing special.  Had some fried Rice and Steak on New Year's Day.  Service lagged, even for hungover visitors.

I liked this place mainly for the atmosphere. They also have a very large menu, so you have plenty of things to choose from. My husband had the pad thai, and I had the pork neck with jasmine rice and we shared spring rolls for the appetizer. We both had some wine, which they have a good selection of as well. 
The same with most places on the strip, it's over priced for the food. My husband and I eat a lot of Asian cuisine, and in my opinion, I've just had much better for a more reasonable price. The service was not very good either. They weren't insanely busy, but it took 30 minutes to get rice that I had ordered with my meal. I had to ask 3 times before I got it. 
I'm sure I would eat there again, but only if it was convenient.
Came here for dinner and waiting for the rest of the group to arrive before I heart radio festival. The best plate was this coconut rice mango dessert. It's so addicting.

I decided to try lemongrass after learning about it on a previous visit. A great tip...the restaurant does take out...so I ordered green chicken curry & drunken noodles. The green curry was pretty tasty with a nice amount of heat whereas the drunken noodles were terribly bland. The price was good...2 dishes + rice for $42 is like finding Vegas best kept secret! (Just ask for medium spice for the drunken noodles)

This is probably one of the best meals I had while I was in Vegas
Went here after reading other Yelp reviews.
We started with an order of the potstickers. So good.  Hot, fresh, and the sauce was scrumptious
Eric and I both had the Pad Thai. He had tofu and I had shrimp. So good. I like to judge a place on their Pad Thai. My expectations were met. 
The staff was super nice and helpful. My water glass was never empty, which is important when at a Thai restaurant. 
I definitely recommend this place if you're in Vegas.

The food arrived late and it was cold. The food absolutely had no flavor at all. The waiter ignored our instructions entirely. We asked our food to be spicy and it was no where near to that. I would really look at other Thai restaurant on a strip that has better service and flavorful food.

FYI, I think this is the first Thai restaurant I've seen in a Vegas resort, which is good. Variety is always good. 

We ordered the rib eye steak, duck red curry, and two other dishes I barely remember.  The duck curry was hands down the best.  It was really tasty, if a tad sweet.  The crappy part about the dish was that there was barely any duck in it.  What duck it did have was tender and well-cooked.  

I only ate a piece of the steak - it was ok.  The other two dishes I don't remember were average. We also had spring rolls with cream cheese inside - strange, but not bad.  

Overall, the food was fine.  It's friggin pricey for Thai food ($30+ per person after tax and tip), but that's probably the cheapest place to eat at in Aria, next to the crap-tacular cafe they have. And maybe the buffet which judging from reviews, is pretty crap-tastic itself.

Service here, unlike the rest of Aria, was actually okay.  I only had to ask for the check twice.  The food, water, etc. and everything all came out okay. 

If I was fiending for Thai food and I was in or near Aria, I'd come by.  It's not really worth a detour.

At first I was very surprised by its three star review. The I realized why as my meal progressed.
Decided to come here for lunch since we wanted something inside the hotel to save time, and most other restaurants were closed for lunch.
Promptly seated when we arrived, and they informed us there was still dim sum being served so we were pretty excited. The food is Chinese and Thai, even though they call themselves a Thai restaurant.
So they actually pushed around some dim sum on a cart. We ordered a bunch of things and the guy pushing the cart was a pretty good salesman because we ended up with a bunch of stuff, and he spoke Cantonese as well. Most of the dim sum dishes were b/n $5-7. Definitely more expensive than most restaurants.
Chicken feet - 3.5 stars, I like dim sum king better, but it was decent.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=eI9PBrgTDLA7H7pJy1mEXw\
Shark fin dumpling - 3.5 stars, tasted fresh and not too bad. But I've never been a huge fan because I don't really like cilantro.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=-ry4GWNxlXF2K5xWH9Mpew
Stick rice in lotus leaf - 4.5 stars. This was really good. Very flavorful, filled with lots of meat, and they used regular shrimp rather than dried shrimp.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=uquHg71LwLDWok7uSHRd8w
The next three is part of dim sum but it was not readily available on the cart. But it only took a few minutes from the point of ordering to arrival.
Stuffed crab claw - 4 stars, it tasted really fresh and filled with crab and shrimp compared to most dim sum places. However as you eat the claw you can taste that it's been previously frozen. Fresher than other places, but not completely fresh. Didn't care for the mayo that came with it, just used chili sauce and soy sauce. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=3nvHw_BHvGUeHjC72yuRVQ
Curry pork bun and basil chicken bun. I like the curry pork bun, didn't taste so much like curry but had a little kick and lots of flavor. I thought the basil chicken tasted a little bland but my bf liked it.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=eQm37SiDOa4Nhz4-RgV_IQ
We had ordered off the regular menu and was waiting on the rest of our food. We picked the basil meatball soup, chicken curry, and after reading good reviews for the satay, I opted for the lobster satay.
They bring out the food, and despite repeating lobster satay back to me, they brought a lobster salad. I informed them that it was the wrong item, so they took the salad away and one can only assume that they were suppose to bring me my satay.
Basil meatball soup $9 - 4 stars. FIlled with tender soft meatballs, and loaded with lots of basil leaves. The soup was light and refreshing, and the immense taste of basil left my mouth feeling refreshed. Not too greasy, and perfectly seasoned.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=96Sz_IJDONzTffXoJBk9Ug
Curry - 3 stars. Tasted like everywhere else to me, the only bonus is that it was loaded with potatoes. My bf actually didn't like the curry and he only ate a little bit of it. I barely touched it so we threw most of it away.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/N7yuiiu8jhQ-Fl9Npflreg?select=BfPRtLtMz5sWYqgKvOf-tA
So about 30-35 minutes have past since they brought me the wrong dish. We are completely done eating and still nothing. Took us about 5 more minutes to flag down out waiter, even though it was not busy at all. And he said that it's almost ready. I didn't even really want it at this point. But he just said it was coming and ran off. Waited waited waited...... 5 more minutes passes by, so I was like forget it, let's go this is stupid. It doesn't take 45 minutes to make satay. So another 5 minutes passes before we find out waiter again and ask for the bill.
So guess what, they CHARGED me for the lobster satay that I DIDN"T eat and I DIDN"T receive. Are you kidding me?????????
