So his explanation was he took off the dim sum items instead. Well he took off three dim sum items that added up to $18 while my satay was $22, so WTF. It's not about $4, because even then our lunch was well over $100. I don't care about $4. I care about the principle that you did not serve me well, and you want to rip me off additionally. Why can't you just reverse the satay?? Why must you do some funky thing and take off three dim sums that adds up to less than my satay? Seriously?????????
I would NEVER eat here again. I am surprised for a wonderful hotel like Aria that they would even have a restaurant like this. The service is so below par. Unfortunately I wrote a 20%+ tip before I saw the charges.

I always stayed at Aria when I went to Vegas since it opened for the last 10 times I've visited. I am really disappointed. Avoid this place, NOT WORTH IT. Such shady business practices.

Pretty good Thai food for the Strip.  Came here for dinner one night on my last trip here, and had a great experience over all.  Our server was really nice and friendly and food was brought out appropriately rather than all at once.  He was patient with our drink orders and was able to make substitutions to some of our entrees as well.

Cocktails are all pretty good here.  I had the Watermelon Caipiroska and it was a table favorite.  Really tasty and refreshing without being overly sweet.  You can't even taste the liquor in here.  My sister had the Berry Botanical, but the green tea was a little overpowering.  The Ginger Peach was good too but the vodka does come through even with the black tea.  Wine list is decent and included a really tasty Pinot from Holdredge.  I loved how the wine list was broken down between delicate and full-bodied.

For appetizers, we started with Chicken Satay and Veggie Spring Rolls.  Satay was tasty with a really good peanut sauce, served with skewers poked into a pineapple chunk.  Spring rolls were standard but good.  For dinner, I split an order of Dan Dan noodles and Basil Chicken with another member of our party.  We sub'd the minced pork with sliced chicken, but ended up getting minced chicken which worked out just fine.  Didn't realize it was going to come out as soupy as it did, but that was OK.  The chili oil and peanut combination gave it a nice sweet and sour taste.  The basil chicken was AMAZING.... all the pieces of meat were so tender and juicy.  The flavors were amazing... we couldn't stop eating!  We skipped dessert here, but I am sure there were some treats on there.

After a late show my mom and I got back to the hotel around 11:30. Many places are closed but they have later hours. Their cocktails are very nice, and their beer selection is large. The potstickers are delicious, and they can make many dishes steamed instead of stir-fried which is better for health conscious people. The sorbet and ice cream are also excellent dessert options.

If you are staying at Aria- this thai restaurant is probably the most affordable one aside from their lunch buffet.  
Just make sure that you specify the degree of spicyness that you want. We wanted a 2/10 but it tasted like 6/10. 10 as the most spicy and 1 as the least.  I liked their salmon roll. I would not recommend the spicy lobster salad.

Stop by here if you like Thai food and if you are near Aria.!

Prices are reasonable, for good Thai Food. This is where I discovered my love for   TOM KHA GAI  (coconut, chicken, thai garlic, mushroom and lemongrass, i  dont like mushrooms and if you dont too, still try it cuz its not one to miss) So much flavor.

Also ordered the salmon spring rolls, satay, and pad thai (pad thai was nothing special, but still good =).

Service: waiter look straight out of animae comic book very polite, food took awhile but well worth the wait!

Ambiance was very clean, simple and cozy.

Love this place!

The food was good... But not great. The Tom yum soup with mushroom was awesome but the garlic shrimp dish was a bit bland. Not enough flavors for my personal taste. Also the entrees didn't come with rice... Service was good but not great either. Servers were very friendly but I always had to look for them and wave at them to get my cup filled with water. But I love the atmosphere and their prices which is not bad at all for a restaurant on the strip. So I will come again whenever I crave Thai food.

First off, the place is very nice looking. We were excited to eat there, but the aesthetics were about the end of our enjoyment.

We started with potstickers which were good, but nothing special. 

We decided to try out a couple of soups, the wonton noodle soup and a duck and BBQ beef soup. They were just terrible. They tasted like mop water. Our server did not drop them off and never returned to check on us or refill our waters. We finally flagged him down to get our check. He saw our uneaten meals and asked if we wanted to-go boxes. We told him no and he said okay and went to get the check. He never asked if we liked the food or why we didn't eat more of it.

I'm sure there are other options that we would have enjoyed, but we won't be back to try them.

Bad service led to bad food led to a bad experience.

I said "I'm vegan." The hostess manager (I forgot her name...maybe Santara or something? She is Thai, I believe.) suggested the panang curry. I aked her if it could be made completely mild. She said yes. I had my doubts, and confirmed again.

Turns out she didn't know the menu.

My takeout order came and I left to eat it. Spicy. Sweating. Nose running. Not pleasant for this Midwesterner. Didn't...couldn't enjoy the meal (which was only brown rice and tofu in panang sauce...No veggies.)  Brought it back and complained. Asked what we could do. She said we couldn't do a refund. I said fine, then how about a free dessert? She said she would "talk to the chef" to see what could be done. Last time I checked, the chef takes orders from the manager, and will prepare whatever. She comes back with a scoop of ice cream (for a vegan). I send it back. She coffees back with a few pieces of watermelon that didn't look all that appetizing. Gotta say, they tastes great. But, I think she should have given me a choice. If she would have, I would have chosen and been restored to good. The way she treated me, she gets yelped at.

The meat sticks were awesomely flavorful with nice presentation. The food arrived quickly, hot and fresh. Our server was the best part as he seemed happy and responsive and took great care of our table of 6 easily.  Given this isn't the nicest Thai available, it's still good value and a great location!  I'm also not a seafood eater which the menu choices had plenty to accomodate all tastes.

Food: good
Service: great
Decor and Ambiance: great

The food was good but I did not see how it was better than the regular neighborhood thai joint.
I tried the basil fried rice and it was really very satisfying but nothing that would justify the $18 price point.
Maybe I did not get the right thing.

Overall would try someplace else unless I want thai food.

Thank you

If I couldn't get all the meals comped at this place, I'm not sure I would eat here. But all the meals are free from my poker comps so I'm here more than I would if free market forces were applied.

The Soft-shelled crab fried rice is really really good fried rice. With that said, it's fried rice and it costs something like 30 dollars. They also have a slew of dishes and you can adjust the "hotness level" on a scale of 1-10. I've tried level 5 and 8, and the dish that was the 5 was more spicy than some of the 8's, so I think it's spotty. If you like your stuff spicy, 8 is a good level.

I don't remember all the other dishes I tried, but they are all decent.

I would give it 5 stars if the food was serve a little faster.  I went with small children, and it took almost 40 minutes to get our dishes out.  Don't get me wrong, the food was fantastic. We ordered too little so I asked the waiter if we could order another dish, but I was afraid it would be another 30+ minutes. He was really great and apologized for the delay. He assured us that if we wanted to order another dish, it would be quick. And it was.  The char kwe tiau was excellent.  Very expensive place, but very good.  3 dishes for almost $80!

Food was good and I thought the prices for a restaurant in a very nice hotel like the Aria were reasonable.  I had a problem with the service however.  We ordered 2 appetizers,  lobster soup, 4 entrees.  I specifically asked the server that they bring the food in the order I show above.  Appetizers came and we finished them, they cleared the table and then the soup and all the entrees showed up.  The soup takes time to serve and eat and by the time you're finished then the entrees aren't as hot as you would like.  A nice place like this should know better.  I was PO'ed at their mistake and at myself for not sending the entrees back.  I made sure the server knew I wasn't happy but he only apologized but did not offer desserts for the 4 of us or to reduce the bill.  I won't return.

We started with some cocktails at the bar. The Watermelon cocktail was good. The spice Thai cocktail was beyond excellent. Ordered the spicy cucumbers-lots of garlic and spice but I dig that combo! The cucumbers look soggy but are still crispy. For entree we got three items:
sweet and sour chicken-pretty normal. 
Veggie Padseyew -liked this
Soft shell crab fried rice- amazing, lots of crab and the soft shell crab was a perfect crisp! 
Bartender, hostess, and waiter were all nice. Overall great experience and will be back.

Everytime I am in vegas i make it a point to go here. 
The staff are couteous. Food tastes amazing. You cant go wrong with anything . Their noodles and fried rice are my favorite 
The ambiance is really good.
In the mood for pho and it was good. They also have other noodles and Asian cuisine.  Excellent service in a great atmosphere.
Slow service, and the mee goring tasted literally like noodles in tomato sauce. definitely a miss.

my dad wanted to try this place out, so we decided to go. the decor is nice, unlike the food.. 
I ordered the roasted duck and bbq pork noodles, and I was very disappointed. the only thing good about it was the pork. the duck had too many bones and barely any meat, the soup was very oily and lacked flavor, the vegtables weren't cooked all the way, and neither were the noodles. my dad ordered pad thai. he told them no peanuts but they still put some on the plate. the server was nice enough to go fix that. other than that, my dad said the pad thai was okay, nothing special. 
I decided to give the place another chance. I ordered pad kee mao spicy 4/10. I'm not sure how they measure their spicy level, but I did say 4/10, which shouldn't be all that spicy.. but it was. I couldn't enjoy it because my tongue was burning. but there was so much wrong with this, I don't even.. ok, so aside from the spiciness, the meat and especially the vegtables were inconsistently cut. majority of the pieces were very big as well as very undercooked. another thing was that the noodles were hardly seperated; most of the noodles were still stuck together. lastly, there was so much basil.. again, aside from it being not cooked properly, there was so much that I had it in every bite, it was overpowering.
that being said, I would not come here again, and I would definitely not recommend this place to anyone. it's just bad food for an expensive price.

Service was exceptional!!! (if you have never been out of the country the service will seem odd because they will not bring you the check until you directly ask for it) Food was really good. It is a little bit pricey, but to be expected in a nice hotel on the strip.

A solid 3.6 stars.  Tried the Beef Pho, Wonton Noodle Soup (wontons were huge half shrimp, half pork.  Could not finish.  All dining partners were happy also, decent and fresh food, though not over the top delicious.  Would return though.
Really good thai food, if you are brave  try the jelly fish. The dungenous crab curry was the best thing on the menu.

Read all the reviews and decided to take a chance for lunch....  this is definitely a 3 -star establishment.  The restaurant decor is beautiful.  The food is mediocre at best.  This is not a thai restaurant, but a restaurant with south east asian cuisine.  You will be dissapointed if you think you are going to get good thai food here.  Thought they had the dim sum cart, but that is only offered on the weekends - Fri, Sat, Sun.  

We had the bacon satay.  The server said it was fatty and no kidding, it was.  It was not like the bacon you have at breakfast, but a fatty piece of pork.  You get 4 skewers.  I could barely take 1 down.   

We had the Drunken Noodle with Seafood, the Softshell Crab fried rice and the grilled pork neck.  The best dish was the drunken noodle.  It had a nice basil flavor to the noodle.  I could not find the seafood, except for 2 shrimp and 1 scallop.  

The soft shell crab fried rice was okay at best.  Lots of crab, but it seemed that they did not clean the body of the crab well, as it tasted really gutty and had a strong fish smell.  The fried rice was like any other asian fried rice.  Nothing special. 

The grilled pork neck was the best dish.  The sauce was exceptional.  It did not sound like a great dish, but it was.  Very lean pork with a soy, mandarin, lime sauce.  Very tasty.  

Service was okay.  Jeremy was a decent server.  The busboys were able to keep up with the iced tea and water service.  We drink fast and a lot, so anyone who can keep up with us, is fantastic.

I was craving Thai food after one of the many shows we saw and decided on lemongrass. Wow. Food was delicious and fresh. I had the cashew nut chicken and my boyfriend had the green curry w chicken. Both were perfectly seasoned and the rice was cooked to perfection. It wasn't anything fancy or expensive and was super delicious and a perfect after show meal. The ambience was quiet and simple. Nothing Vegas style about it... But definitely amazing food and good service. Would go again.

I really enjoyed that they had dim sum on the weekend. Not the best but not too bad.. Their pad Thai is really delicious and their yellow curry as well.. I came here a couple months before and their portions got a little bigger..

Great food and great service. We had a group of 7, all of us very different eaters. I had the panang curry because its my go to dish when i eat Thai. Their version had lychees in it and oh man was the spice on point. Loved everything about it. We also had the cumber salad (perfectly spicy and crunchy), the drunken noodles, and several others dishes, and no one was disappointed! Definitely would go back again!

Lemongrass is a nice, classy restaurant with pretty good food.  Not spectacular or incredibly creative, but satisfying.  We ate the spring rolls and pad thai, and both were just fine.  We also ate the mushroom basil steamed rice, and the flavor combination of tender mushrooms, red peppers, and basil was really nice.

The service was a bit slow, but our server was really nice and friendly.  Lemongrass is a nice restaurant and the food is good, but I wouldn't add this to any must-dine restaurant lists.

Great quiet restaurant when you are in the busy world of Las Vegas.  All of our meals were exceptional, and the drinks were such a tasty treat.  

I would recommend if you are into spicy do not be afraid to have them kick it up a notch, the "medium" for the curry is pretty tame. So if you are just looking for the curry flavor it is great, but tell them to spice it up for you if you want.

We had an early evening menu. It isn't on the menu but ask for it. It contains of a vegetable spring roll with a fish cake. As an main course it is steamed rice, garlic prawn, and green chicken curry and as finish with coconut milk with some vegetables. 
It was the best Thai I have ever had and it is with a relaxing quiet atmosphere a topspot to go to. The vegetables were all wonderfull cooked and vere tastefull. For sure we are coming back here

I enjoyed the drunken noodles, but my one complaint was that when the waitress asked me about the spiciness I said medium to hot and this turned into a conversation that medium was a 3 on a scale of 1-10, which seemed odd for medium. I didn't want to get smoked out but didn't want to have it too bland so I took the 3. If I went back, I would ask for 5 for spiciness. Place was good though.

Been here lots of times they deserve a good review! AWESOME place ! what more can I say ! You can't find fine dinning during lunch hours Well lighted Our host and server is top notch! I and 3 other friends had lunch on 5.22.14 we started with appetizers shrimp and salmon satay, crispy squid, prawn rolls and bamboo shoots all EXCELLENT flavor ! Main course  Soup tom Yam Hed, garlic shrimp, ribeye Tamarin, 3 cup chix, soft crab  fried rice all EXCELLENT !!! For dessert the BOMB ! Drum roll BUA LOI !  My friends said no more food ..... But we need to eat desserts .... They reply no no no more... I ordered anyway .... When they took the first scoop and tasted it ... They went WOW!!! Bill added up to 199.00 that's great ! We'll recommend .... Like what we say in Hawaii for good food is BROKE DA MOUTH ! Lol

It's easily my fave restaurant at the Aria. As soon as I landed at McCarran, all I could think about was the char kway teow at Lemongrass.

Was it the best? Mh.. No. However, they do it right and it always tastes good to me. I will always try to squeeze two portions of it per one Vegas trip. 

Other than my beloved char kway teow, I never really tried anything else here except the chicken and corn soup and mee goreng. Friends ordered the dan dan noodle, drunken noodle, and pad see ew. I was always sticking with my shrimp char kway teow cooked spicy. Sooo good!!!

The restaurant was next to the baccarat lounge and across from Blossoms Chinese Restaurant. It caters mostly to South East Asian foods. This hotel is smart as there are tons of S.E Asians that gamble hugely here. My friend, CK, recommended this place several years back and I still love it to this day. He told me to get a fried garlic crab this time. He said it was out of this world. I didn't get it though because I couldn't eat a whole crab alone.

I'm a big fan! The service is always pretty quick, perfect if you were trying to slip in lunch in between meetings. We were in a time constraint to watch Zarkana, and they did an awesome job in getting the foods we ordered in record time. 

When in Vegas and you like South East Asian cuisines-Thai, Vietnamese, Malaysian, Singaporean, and Indonesian... Lemongrass is the place!

Food was very lackluster. Very bland and tasteless.  Singapore noodles was not to par.  Spring rolls tasted like the ones you get from a fast food Chinese restaurant. Vegetable and tofu dish lacked seasoning.  Plus slow service and waiter with attitude.
Excellent food!!! Pad Thai out of this world!!!! Wonderful atmosphere, great food...I would give 5 stars, but the service was lacking. P.S. Rope art on pointe!

The best thing about this place is that they open late EVERYDAY! That's a big convenience for us staying at Aria Sky suites, the restaurant is located right next to the Sky suites tower. We ordered some simple items and a Goose Bloody Mary to go. After too much partying on Saturday, both hubby and I were extremely tired and in serious need of some Asian food! 

We ordered garlic wings, wonton noodle soup and hot & sour soup, all hangover cure food of course! The hot and sour soup had no shredded pork in it, just generous amount of veggies in very sour and fairly spicy hot soup, that was all I needed at the moment! Hubby loved the garlic wings and wonton egg noodle soup, extremely flavorful and very delicious! 

We felt so much better after some super yummy Thai food, glad we decided to take advantage of this opening late restaurant, we really had no energy to get out of Aria hotel to find comfort Asian food at midnight. 

Ps. was too tired to take photos.

So so disappointing. We just completed a great stay at the Aria, and everything was fantastic EXCEPT for the birthday dinner at Lemongrass I arranged for my husband. First, we waited forever to get our food. Several tables that arrived later than us were severed, while we still waited. The waiter came by three times to remind us it was cooking and on its way. Alone, I wouldn't consider this terrible, but then the food arrived. Mine was not edible as the chicken in the dish was so salty I could not eat it. My husband had Pad Thai, but there were almost no noodles in it. I've had better Pad Thai at home, let alone pay this much for it. When I made our reservation, I was assured my husband's birthday would be acknowledged at dessert, but when it was time.....nothing! And at that point, we had no time to argue with them as it was time for us to go to our show. I expect better from the Aria.
Amazing pho, probably the best since most places suck local to me in the DC, MD, VA area compared to this restaurant!

I had the Mee Goreng entree. Noodles were thicker like pasta (which I wanted) but unfortunately, it tasted like an Italian pasta dish more than the spicy noodles I was craving.. I might go back, but definitely would not recommend that dish.
Went here for dinner. The atmosphere is very romantic and uptown. Their tom yum soup is a surprise, delicious!!

Went there for a late night bite so we chose something that won't be too greasy. The food is alright, not too impressive. The only thing that made me remember this restaurant is that we happen to chat with the chef and he ended up offering us two deserts on the house. :)

Came into Lemongrass for a late dinner. This place should not be confused with the many amazing restaurants at the Aria Blossom. The Asian restaurant  directly across is a lot better. However, this place is open until 2am and it serves mediocre Chinese food. I'm from NY, home of the best Chinese food, so I know. All other restaurants close at 11 in the Aria so this restaurant is more of a cafe and has a fancy decor, staying consistent with the Aria.

This would usually be a 5 star review, as I have been here many times. However, this last visit was less than good. The yellow curry came out far to spicy despite saying spicy level 2. When I asked the dish to be remade the waiter was less that kind and tried to tell me there was no spice in the dish. I can handle spicy. In fact I usually order spicy 7. On this particular evening it was late and I was not into spicy. I would still recommend trying it out. This was my first off experience in six times eating there.

Went here for a business meeting last month and decided that we should go out for some good ol Thai food. 

I ordered the classic Pad Thai and shared some noodle and rice dishes with my fellow co workers. It was actually not too bad for a restaurant inside a hotel! The decor was very nice and clean. Service was prompt, just didn't blow me away. I will keep this restaurant in mind, the next time I am back in Sin City:)
Taste explosion!  Generous portions. Beautiful setting. Forget Julian Serrano. Eat here.

Since we were seeing Zarkana we wanted to eat in the Aria. I really loved the atmosphere and decor, like all of the Aria it stands out.

Our waiter was really nice especially when I asked for a unique drink he took my order and delivered exactly what I requested.

We started with the Chicken Satay the best dish of the night, the sauce was a perfect mixture of sweet and spicy. If you go order this!

For dinner we shared the Basil Chicken and Phad See Ew Moo. The flavor was great on both of them however the meats were overcooked and a little chewy. I would expect a place like this to have proper cooking time and not overcook their dishes. 

Also someone goes around to take pictures of you. However they are $50 for two pictures so be prepared.

Finding good food in Vegas without trading in arm or a leg can be difficult to say the least! Lemongrass is in the Aria Hotel which is a beautiful hotel and it is in a great area, the City Center. I tried the Drunken Noodle with Shrimp and I was blown away at how good it was. I was also blown away by how spicy it was even though I was informed it would be medium. Despite this glitch the food was divine and reasonably priced and the service outstanding!
Not sure why this place has 3.5 stars. I have been here over 10 times and never disappointed. Food and service always consistent. If you sit at the bar, make sure you see Tony!

Tasty food, good service, and great ambiance.. but be careful with the spice level on the orders. We had it as #7 but it turned out to be way to much. Being Indian I can handle a high spice level but this definitely gave me a good run for my money. So I suggest 3-4 but if you're daring enough or drunk enough lol.. go for the 7 ;)

We were staying at ARIA for the weekend , so before heading out to party the night away, one of my friend suggested we grab something to eat at the hotel... At first we wanted Sushi, But walked by Lemongrass and the place seems really cozy and cute so we just decided to walk in and try this place out. 

Boy, was I glad we did.  The food was so good.  The menu consist of all the typical Thai entrees, like pad thai and all the thai soup BUT because we were in vegas, we wanted to go the exotic route and try different stuff on the menu.  There was 6 of us girls and we decided to do family style and order 6 entrees and shared.  We got the Soft shell fried rice, beef pepper udon noodles , fish cakes, a coconut soup , coconut flavored rib eyed and a WONTON NOODLE SOUP ( for the girl that was hungover from friday nite)  

I must say...everything was really good but the soft shell fried rice... WOW.. the fried rice had big chunks of the crab meat in it.. and let me say.. they were not greedy with it at all.. there was also large soft shell crab on top of the fried rice.  IT was sooo GOOD.   the Rib eye wasnt too bad either , although im more of a seafood person than a meat eater.  

The prices here , of course, was a bit pricey compared to other thai restaurant, BUT we are in Vegas!!.  But we all agreed that you get what you pay for and the food was worth the price!!

Absolutely dreadful, don't waste your time. 

Decided to try this out the Saturday after Christmas. Wish I hadn't bothered. The restaurant serves Thai food although you wouldn't know this as they don't display a menu outside! We didn't have a reservation but went just after 9pm and could see that the restaurant was only half full. Asked for a table for 2 when the girl at the desk finally returned and she said she could see what she could do! She managed to find us a table but really didn't seem to know what she was doing. 

We ordered and this is when we should have realised there would be a problem. The table next to us asked for the manager to complain about something, we should have left then! However, I know they had only been open just over a week so I thought it wouldn't be too bad. Little did I know. 

We ordered a satay and salmon roll to start and then chicken green curry. I wanted chicken satay but was told there was no chicken satay and I could have pork instead. Why could they not put chicken on a stick??? Had they run out of pre-prepared chicken satay? We also ordered a bottle of wine. 

After around 15 minutes our waiter brought a glass of wine. Oh dear, but not the end of the world as this was easy to fix. He brings the bottle back and then proceeds what seems like at least 5 minutes trying to open it. I have never seen anyone spend so long trying to open a bottle of wine. I almost asked for the corkscrew myself as it was embarrassing to watch him fumble with it. When he finally opened it he then dropped the cork in the wine cooler! He certainly wasn't used to opening wine and by the way he slouched around the restaurant and didn't seem to know what he was doing I got the impression that he hadn't worked in a restaurant before. 

By this point the couple at the table next to us had been sitting there around 10 minutes without a menu and if their body language was anything to go by they weren't having a fun evening.The woman next to them was sat with arms folded staring towards the kitchen too. 

Had a glass of wine (this was nice) and then another. By this point I'm wondering where on earth the food was. We weren't drinking fast and I know that some sort of food should have arrived before we'd had 2 glasses of wine each. I then see a table opposite (who had arrived quite some time after us) being served food. I check my watch and it is almost 1 hour after we arrived. We call the manager over and ask what is going on and where our food was. He returns to say that there has been a problem with the order being put into the system (ie it wasn't!). I'd had enough by now and say we would like to leave and we'd pay for the wine. He tells us he'll take car of the wine for us and we leave. 

This is the first time I have left a restaurant before even eating. I understand that they had only just opened and were bound to have some teething problems but half of the staff seemed completely useless and lacked any experience. There were a couple of people rushing around and looked like they had worked in restaurants before but the majority of them were clueless. No one spotted that we never had any food in almost an hour and the manager was stood practically next to us the entire time! 

One more small thing, I was sat on a comfy seat but my husband said the chair he was sitting on was incredibly uncomfortable (he mentioned this just after arriving too so it was nothing to do with the wait).

Just make sure to go past the incompetent hostess at the front with communication problems, who will make you wait for a table for 30 minutes for absolutely no reason, tell you to go take a walk, when there are tables available, and go straight to Eric at the bar. He will take care of you. Thanks Eric! 
(And by the way, after we were already at the bar for 10 minutes and ordered apps she tried to come get us for a table.)

Absolutely no taste whatsoever, the foods are very plain, cold and the meats tasted like they have not marinaded or any ingredients have been added.  The service is very slow and lousy, it was not busy period. We don't recommend it. We will never come back unless they change to different Thai chef.
The atmosphere is very nice, but my pad thai haf no flavor at all. If you have a car drive to Lotus of Siam.

One of the best Thai food I had till now. Panang curry with duck is flavorful and heavenly! Pad Thai was just ok. Not worth the price imo. The interior decor is perfect .Not recommended if you are on a budget as it is definitely a posh restaurant, but you are in Aria and can't expect anything less, but I would still go there just to have the Panang duck curry !

Lemongrass was our first stop after checking in at our hotel. I was seriously hungry, overwhelmed by the Vegasness of Vegas, and super grumpy. The yellow curry was like an elixir. It came in a huge bowl, and even though I was hungry (I mean, really really really hungry), I couldn't finish the whole thing. It didn't come with everything that was listed as being in it on the menu, but when I mentioned it, our waitress was quick to correct the problem. She wasn't my favorite server ever -- it was a very generic and impersonal experience -- but she was nice and helpful, and although I like more, I don't feel like I can expect that. 

My boyfriend got the vegetable fried rice, which was also really good. Both of us enjoyed our food so much that for the rest of the trip we kept talking about going back there instead of trying other restaurants. 

The experience wasn't 100%, but the food was so good and generously portioned that it actually merited the price. We only went there once on this trip, but I'm sure we'll be back again on a future trip.

We love Thai food so we are always looking to try something new. We stopped by here for dinner after a day of walking around. The food was ok- it does not make the top 5 Thai places on my list. I asked for spicy and it wasn't. The food was way over priced. 

The decor is beautiful but that doesn't make my belly full.

First thing you think of when you go into the Aria Hotel is bling bling, I must be getting paper fo'sho if i'm staying here. That ubiquitous air of wealth and luxury permeates the atmosphere, you can't help but feel like Justin Bieber in Vegas. You're the bomb; anything is possible in sin city. With this new found confidence and flare for extravagance, what sort of dining experience do you expect? I'm thinking exotic. I'm thinking fantabulous. I'm thinking thai food.

So, during my short stay at the Aria hotel in Las Vagas, me and my family decided to go to Lemongrass. First of all, the decor was amazing. Curtains of fringe hung effortlessly on the ceiling, creating a tent over some of the tables. The lights were dim, creating a very sensual atmosphere, mimicking that oriental mysteriousness of Asia. Om nom nom nom, this place looks amazing!

I wish i could say the same about the food. It was like turning on the T.V, being all excited to watch the new episode of the Real Housewives of New York, but getting disappointed when instead, you see the rerun of a cheap, tacky real housewife of New Jersey flipping a table. Don't tase me bro! I love the Manzos and all, but the Simon and Alex are where it's at! Anyway, back to the food, I could have gotten tastier, more authentic thai food at half the price right here in OC. Don't get me wrong though, the food wasn't horrible, it was very much delicious.  For appetizers, we ordered the Yam Ta Krai (lemongrass, fresh prawns, squid, scallops, spicy tamarind dressing) and Tom Yam Talay soup (spicy seafood, prawns, scallop, squid, lemongrass, abalone mushrooms).The appetizers were amazing! The seafood was super fresh, and everything was really tasty and flavorful.

What I was really disappointed in were the entrees. I hate curry...NOT. I'm bananas for curry. Everytime I eat thai food, which is very often, I order curry again and again and again. I would bathe in curry and immerse myself in its deliciousness if I could. Curry is better than shark week; it is legend...wait for it...dary. So, i ordered the green curry since it came with eggplant ( eggplant is a sign God wants us to be happy). I didn't hate it, I could never hate curry. It would be like a mother hating her child. It was just watered down and lacked that unctuous and satisfying spice that curry is supposed to have. My mom ordered the Drunken Noodles, which I guess is one of their specialties. To be honest, these noodles tasted like a typical msg-ridden fried noodle dish from a mediocre Vietnamese restaurant. The crisp on the noodles was nice; but like the curry, it lacked flavor. 

The dessert was amazing though! But then again, I've never complained about the dessert at any restaurant. Dessert is like Ryan Gosling; it's good all the time. I ordered mango sticky rice, a thai classic! If you've never had mango sticky rice, you have never lived. The red ruby was very tasty as well. It was shaved ice with corn, jellies, and jack fruit. The corn was a sweet, surprising touch. 

Overall the restaurant was average. I would give ten stars for the decor but only three stars for the actual food. Compared to the prices of other shnazzy Vegas restaurants, this place was a pretty good deal. But compared to a more humble, authentic thai restaurant, the food seemed bland. If you want super yummy, exotic drinks, appetizers, and deserts with a cool and stylish ambiance, definitely try this place!

Goto spot for my late night poker session refueling. 

My go to dish is the Chicken PadThai. Big portions and fresh. 
Lemongrass always gets my comps and always will. 


Props to Aria for having great food selection for casino/poker room players.

Come here everytime we are in Vegas!  Though this time the service was terrible I will be back to try it again.  I've never had bad serivce here before.  The food is amazing.  I love the thai basil chicken.  The decor is amazing.  A must if your in Vegas.
Awesome dim sum on Fridays 11am-3pm

Beautiful decor and a relaxing atmosphere.  Food was great. Ribeye steak was cooked perfectly and served with amazing little mushrooms. 

Service was very poor. They have some sort of cart that comes around offering a table side service but we couldn't understand what the guy was saying...eventually he just walked away.  The other servers were okay. Not on the level of other restaurants in this price range.  

Pot stickers appetizer, ribeye for me, some sort of spicy chicken soup for her, and two  "specialty" drinks came to $75 with tip.  I'd go back.

Love, love!  I ordered takeout from Lemongrass, and the food was ready even before the estimated wait time.  The customer service was excellent and the employees were very friendly.  I ordered the pad thai and it was outstanding!  There was a balance of spice and sweet, with a great crunch from the peanuts on top.  It was even served with Sriracha and a lime to squeeze on top.  Loved the food!  One of my favorites so far in Las Vegas.

I was craving some Asian food and stumbled upon Lemongrass at Aria. For strip pricing, this place is reasonable for some comfort Thai food. We ate at the bar and were greeted by Tony the bartender. He was very friendly. We ordered some shrimp Phad Thai and also some fish cakes. The fish cakes were really delicious and the pad thai fulfilled my Asian craving. 

I actually came back to this place a couple of hours later because my other friends were also having an Asian food craving. I had the Tom Yam Hed which is a abalone mushroom soup as well as their Singapore Noodles to go which consists of stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, and curry powder. I was amazed by how well the singapore noodles lasted a couple of hours after a late dinner. The soup and the noodles were pretty good. At least I know that the quality of the food is consistent. It is a great place to come if you are indeed staying at Aria.

New dim sum discovery! I am not a dim sum diva, but I was excited to discover they do have the option. We went on a Sunday afternoon, and were surprised to see a list of dumplings on the table. The cart doesn't come around too often, which could be frustrating. From the cart we selected the soup and the spinach and shrimp dumplings. They weren't as piping hot as I might have enjoyed, and the soup dumplings weren't as soupy as your dreams. However, the taste, especially of the shrimp/spinach, was excellent. I would get those again. Plus, the environment is about 5 times nicer than your usual dim sum establishment. We also sampled the chicken wings this time around, and they were surprisingly delicious. Their soft tofu is superb in their curries. They don't take it easy on the spice though, so be careful what you ask for. We also tried the Three Cups Chicken, but for the price and execution, you're better off doubling down on the chicken wings!

The service was good and excellent seafood drunken noodles with shrimp, scallops and squid. I order 5 level spice and need to add spice for my taste which I think is medium ( no nose running but nice heat). If your like medium spice probably need 6 or 7.

Wow, this place may have the best vegetarian green curry outside of Thailand! Truly Incredible!!! Also, the overall experience was amazing--great atmosphere and service.  Next time I am in Vegas, I am going to have to revisit this gem.

Despite the 3.5 stars here on Yelp, I decided to try this place out with my aunt since we were both big fans of Thai food. We thought, this restaurant is in Aria... It has to be good, right? I guess the interior can really fool people in terms of quality because this place was just a disappointment. 

Service: 1/5 I have expectations when it comes to upscale restaurants like these because one, we're shelling out a bit more money than a typical restaurant. Two, it's in Aria. I'm pretty sure that they just rent out the space in the hotel, but still, I imagined that they would want to provide the same type of service. 

We were at at our table, and whoever was responsible for taking care of us pretty much neglected us. Getting our drinks was the only fastest part of the service. Everything else was just plain annoying. We waited a bit for our waiter to take our order. Nothing was special about it as he just took the order, and left. All throughout the meal, he never came back to check on us. It was to the point when we were done and STILL waiting. Like, WHY?!

Food: 2/5 I think the chicken satay redeemed itself because that was pretty tasty, but there was nothing special about it. I thought it was beautifully prepared though. We ordered pad thai, pad see ew, and duck panang for the main entree. Both were bland in taste which was such. a. disappointment. Seriously, for the price that we paid for and the taste, it just doesn't match. I can literally go down to an average Thai restaurant here in Vegas, and they would probably taste the same-- Bland. The duck panang was a bit tasty as well but it couldn't hit that "wow' factor. The duck was tender, but the sauce-- not so much. 

Interior: 4/5 This place is beautiful which entices people to walk in and dine with them. I was a fan of the darkly lit room and the positioning of all the booths and tables. Their decor was amazing as well. The overall look of the restaurant is the only reason why I'm giving this review a two star. 

Overall, it was a disappointment. I felt bad enough that my aunt didn't want me to pay for dinner since I was the one that suggested it. Next time, I'm going to take her to my favorite Thai restaurant (which I won't name because that isn't fair) as it doesn't disappoint. I have to say that there are definitely better restaurants out there that can definitely compete with this place.

Standard Thai food. No wait. This place is mostly half full, lots of seating available

For drinks, I got a fresh coconut. It's refreshing with the meal. 

Main entree: vegetarian pad see ew, requested without oyster sauce. Comes with gailan veg, asparagus, oyster mushroom, carrots with the flat noodle. This dish was okay. I found it to be too oily. The veggies were also mostly all stems..
Been here a few times on past Aria visits.  Great heat on the Tom Yum (w/shrimp) and delicious pineapple fried rice.  Grub if you are going to indulge in asian cuisine in house.

Last minute find on a late Sunday night. Amazing food and great service.  We had the chicken and shrimp satay to start. Excellent!  From Start to finish. Ended with deep friend banana and ice cream. Pad thai, panang and rib eye was perfect! Definitely can't wait to go back next time.
Service is great. food is ok some of the appetizer are amazing must try chicken satay and fish cake amazing. One thing that I don't like is the peanut sauce.

It's amazing how you can go to the same restaurant twice and have two completely opposite experiences, one a 5 star and one a 1 star.

We went today at 2:30 pm to eat after an INCREDIBLE experience 11pm Saturday night. Saturday night it was fairly empty, and we sat at the bar. A great female bartender took our order, took care of everything with my food allergies, and was overall awesome. The food itself was delicious. 

Today, the food was AWFUL. The service by a bartender again (Shawn) was horrible. He was obviously stressed and not only served us badly (screwed up the order, didn't send my cold app out with my husband's hot app), but didn't even provide silverware or napkins for the people next to us. My order was wrong (I didn't say anything, it wouldn't have gotten me anywhere), and the food runners didn't even seem to know where the food was going and just asked the patrons who ordered chicken satay. 

If you're going to come here, recognize that it's totally hit or miss.

One of the better places for eating thai food on the strip. We were quite sure we could handle spicy and chose to go 5/10, trust me, tears in our eyes, it was burning HOT. But it tasted so good, that we enjoyed finishing our food. I would suggest go for a 3 or a 4 if you are not used to eating spicy food. But the overall ambience and service was excellent.

This place was like an oasis in the desert.  Delicious cocktails like the Chai Spice that was featured on Vegas' M Life magazine, and thai and chinese inspired dishes that reminded us of home (West La).   It was everything we needed to check out of the craziness of Vegas for a couple hours. We sat at the bar both times we visited, and it was chill.  Exactly what we needed after one too many glitzy restaurants/buffets :)

Best Thai restaurant in Vegas!

My girlfriends and I visited Vegas one weekend and we decided to have lunch here since it was conveniently located in the hotel we were staying at. The ambiance of this establishment is very modern with unique decors and embellishments. I definitely felt like dining in a 5-star restaurant at decent entree prices.

We ordered a few dishes to share: basil fried rice, pad thai, three chicken spicy dish along with tom yum soup. The basil fried rice was very flavorful and I could definitely taste the basil! This is probably the best basil fried rice I've had compared to other Thai restaurants I've been to. The pad thai was delish, loved that they put the peanuts and bean sprouts on the side because my dining companions enjoy the noodles without it. The three chicken spicy dish was great! Very flavorful with ample amount of meat. The tom yum was my least favorite, only because it was way to spicy for us! (But that's our fault for ordering it too spicy. They will ask you on a range of 1-10 how spicy you would like your soup.)

Our server was very friendly and sociable. She came around often to replenish our drinks. I would definitely recommend for others to try this place out if you're a fan of Thai food. This restaurant is authentic and uses quality ingredients!

Will definitely be back in the future! :)
Came here after a long drive of 8 hours. Got refreshed after having the awesomest Panang Curry and Pad Thai !! Will definitely visit again.

After reading the reviews here I was not expecting much, but we had comps from the poker room that we could use at this restaurant. We had a first time waiter who was awesome, he ran back to the kitchen when he did not know the answer and helped us pick the right dish. The food was pretty good, and portion sizes were huge, and the dishes were priced right. Great place to grab a quick bite before you head to the Zarkana show.

This place seriously surprised me. Wandered in one day just to see what it was about and was impressed by not only the selection, but the execution, and the staff friendliness.

I expected pretentiousness, overpriced small-portioned dishes, and mediocre flavor. What I actually got (both visits so far), is friendly and responsive service, generous portions, and extremely fresh and well-balanced flavors.

This place is now on my list of places to go every time I'm in Vegas. And it rivals most places I've been to in the Portland, OR area. The prices are a little higher, but not egregious. Myself and two friends had quite a good feast for under $90.

We went to Lemongrass this weekend, since we were visiting Aria for a show, and were craving something spicy. The decor of the restaurant is nice, dark woodwork plus neutrals makes for a cool vibe. The seating was very comfortable --  we were in the sofa booth facing the entrance of the restaurant.

Food ordered: lobster tom kha soup, green curry, vegetable fried rice, and cashew chicken. 

Tom kha soup was really good, perfect spice. We asked for a 7, and got a good runny-nose spicy that we were craving! Only gripe: the soup was big enough for two, but only had 3 small pieces of lobster meat. The green curry was also good. But, wasn't out-of-this-world amazing. It hit the spot. The vegetable fried rice was not as great. It was on the bland side, and a tad oily. The cashew nut chicken had great flavors, lots of cashews. 

I loved how they knew their spice! The dishes weren't bland, and they were spicy enough for us to enjoy, without burning our tongues off! Service was very attentive -- although at times it got overwhelmingly attentive! 

Overall, a bit pricey for the food served, but it's to be expected at a strip restaurant. Good service, and good food. Would def visit again.

Had a good meal tonight at Lemongrass: Tsingtao and Green Curry.  Food: 7 - The curry had these awesome mini-asian eggplants (they look like tomatillos) and tons of creamy, yet spicy (I ordered it as a 7) flavor.  

Service: 8 - Ate at the bar, the bartendress was very attentive and friendly.

Location: 4 - It's a pain in the ass to get here from even 1 hotel over.  I recommend eating here if you're staying at Aria, otherwise that walk home is a terrible terrible thing.   

Other: The bar was STOCKED - I imagine you can get any drink made you could ever want.  It's expensive though, a bottle of Fiji water is $9, and the Tsingtao is $12.

Over-priced Thai food, but else can you expect on the strip. My boyfriend and I were in the mood for Thai food and had limited time for lunch. We walked into the restaurant around noon on Sunday and noticed a sign that they also served dim sum here. Looking at their menu, Lemongrass is advertised as thai food, but there's also chinese and vietnamese food on the menu. 

Thai Iced Tea- (3/5) it was okay, slightly too creamy
Chicken Wings- (3/5) the wings without the sauce didn't have much flavor and tasted better with the sweet chili sauce. However, you can get the sauce from a bottle at an Asian market.
Tom Kha soup- (1/5) enough for 4 bowls, dried chicken pieces and mushy mushroom, no other veggies
Chicken Pad Thai (lvl 6)- (3/5) didn't have the tradition sweet taste of pad thai and tasted mostly like spicy

I think if you're really really craving thai, I guess this place is okay. However, if you can drive a little off the strip, you're better off going to a hole in the wall thai restaurant. You'll probably get much more authentic food for a quarter of the price.
Great  yellow curry, fried squid was really good and loved the pickled cucumber. service was good as well. Would come back!

Well is it Thai or Chinese, they can't make their mind up.
Anyway the Tom Yum Shrimp soup was just lovely many huge shrimp and lots of shitake mushrooms
The Pad Thai was pretty authentic again with huge shrimp.
The duck red curry wasn't my favorite but if you like it very creamy then you would like it more than I did.
Service was impeccable and it's open until 2am!!

Food was very good , however service was the worst we saw the server only 2 times taking the order and paying the bill we had to track down the server to get a bill. Also the hostesses were very condescending and annoying. The staff needs to learn manners and know how to deal with customers

The menu here was very standard American Thai -- nothing out-of-the-ordinary. You've got your Pad Thai, some various noodle dishes, some soups, a few curries, and so forth. Some were dressed up a bit (lobster in the Tom Yum soup), but it was basically a standard menu.

But it was as fresh and clean and well-prepared as any Thai food I've had. Flavors were right-on. The soup was perfectly balanced (cool + hot). My shrimp were nicely crusted. There was a bit too much syrupy sauce on one tofu stir fry dish for my liking, but that was the only loser.

The restaurant is a little hidden in the Aria, and both times we went there was no wait. The price is about the same as the buffet upstairs (which can have long lines!), but the food is definitely a notch higher.

And, they take the heat ratings seriously here. I asked for mine to be 8/10. I'm usually good with the heat but this was a bit too much! (They warned me, so I can't hold it against them.)

Hands down best Thai restaurant I've been too. I love how each item is blazing with flavor. The drunken noodle and sea bass is outstanding. Ive been to many other Thai restaurants and have not been a fan. The atmosphere is calm and relaxing. Pricey, but you're paying for what you get. I recommend the two dishes along with pineapple fried rice if you're a pineapple fanatic.
We stayed at the ARIA and decided to get take out from here one night. The Tom Kha Gai was sooo good & the mixed veggies & rice we're great too. Fresh ingredients and quick service

Food is pretty good here. The service, on the other hand, not so much. Our waitress seemed like she was in a rush.  Hubby tried the tasting menu and I got the black pepper shrimp and veggie drunken noodles.

Lemongrass is so beautiful when you walk in the chandlers are massive - the decor is very inviting... My friend and I dined here tonight... The food was good - I had the egg rolls and a sauteed vegetables w/ rice  sake was very good... My friend had a chicken and beef skewers w/ rice... They are a little pricey for what we had... I could of went to china a go go and got enough to feed 5 ppl... but the customer service was A+
Yummy food and great service. We went for lunch and I'm so glad we did. Everything was fresh, tasty and the perfect amount of spice. I will be returning on my sub sequential visits to Las Vegas.

This place serves Chinese fusion type of food, you could tell a lot of effort was put into it when the plate comes out because of how unique the food is arranged, taste wise is not bad. Servers were attentive. Just overall a nice and romantic place to take a hot date!

My wife and I love this place because it is fast, moderately priced, and great food.  

The first time we ate at Lemongrass, we ordered the Lobster satay as an appetizer.  It was very good, but we did not realize that we would have the option to order dim sum from a cart.  The dim sum is a star at this place.  The dim sum server was very knowledgeable and recommended a few options.  Most of them were from the pot sticker and dumpling family.  Tell them the type of food you like, and your server will help you find something.  You can't go wrong, and each order has about 3 or 4 pieces and runs about $5 each.

The menu is extensive here, and has something for those who like traditional Asian dishes, like my wife who ordered the Singapore Noodles.  I like more Asian-American fare, so I ordered the Beef Chow Fun, it tasted like an Asian version of beef stroganoff.  You could really take the cast iron skillet flavor.  Amazing dish for around $15.  

The service was great, and he had plenty of good suggestions, and drinks were always being filled before we had to ask.
